"Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only\na reading-lamp."
"Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor,\nyou think you would have been sure to have seen it?"
"Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper\nand a hot iron."

div.p: Then Poirot repeated the question he had put to Dorcas:

quote.s: "Did your mistress ever have a green dress?"
"No, sir."
"Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a how do you call it? a sports coat?"
"Not green, sir."
"Nor anyone else in the house?"

div.p: Annie reflected.

quote.s: "No, sir."
"You are sure of that?"
"Quite sure."
"Bien! That is all I want to know. Thank you very much."

div.p: With a nervous giggle, Annie took herself creakingly out of the room. My pent-up excitement burst forth.

quote.s: "I congratulate you! This is a great discovery."
"What is a great discovery?"

"Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That\nexplains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early\nmorning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night."
"So you think that the cocoa mark well what I say, Hastings, the\ncocoa contained strychnine?"
"Of course! That salt on the tray, what else could it have been?"
"It might have been salt,"

div.p: replied Poirot placidly.

I shrugged my shoulders. If he was going to take the matter that way, it was no good arguing with him. The idea crossed my mind, not for the first time, that poor old Poirot was growing old. Privately I thought it lucky that he had associated with him someone of a more receptive type of mind.
Poirot was surveying me with quietly twinkling eyes.

quote.s: "You are not pleased with me, mon ami?"
"it is not for me to dictate to you.\nYou have a right to your own opinion, just as I have to mine."
"Now I have finished with this room. By the way, whose is the\nsmaller desk in the corner?"
"Mr. Inglethorp's."
"Ah!"

div.p: He tried the roll top tentatively.

quote.s: "Locked. But perhaps one of\nMrs. Inglethorp's keys would open it."

div.p: He tried several, twisting and turning them with a practiced hand, and finally uttering an ejaculation of satisfaction.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He tried several twisting and turning them with a practiced hand and finally uttering
quote.s: "Voil ! It is not the key, but it will open it at a\npinch."

div.p: He slid back the roll top, and ran a rapid eye over the neatly filed papers. To my surprise, he did not examine them, merely remarking approvingly as he relocked the desk:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he did not examine them merely remarking
quote.s: "Decidedly, he is a man of method,\nthis Mr. Inglethorp!"

div.p: A "man of method" was, in Poirot's estimation, the highest praise that could be bestowed on any individual.
I felt that my friend was not what he had been as he rambled on disconnectedly:

quote.s: "this boudoir has nothing more to tell us. It did not yield much.\nOnly this."

div.p: He pulled a crumpled envelope out of his pocket, and tossed it over to me. It was rather a curious document. A plain, dirty looking old envelope with a few words scrawled across it, apparently at random. The following is a facsimile of it.
[Illustration]
div.head: CHAPTER V.
div.p: IT ISN'T STRYCHNINE, IS IT?

quote.s: "Where did you find this?"

div.p: I asked Poirot, in lively curiosity.

quote.s: "In the waste-paper basket. You recognise the handwriting?"
"Yes, it is Mrs. Inglethorp's. But what does it mean?"

div.p: Poirot shrugged his shoulders.

quote.s: "I cannot say but it is suggestive."

div.p: A wild idea flashed across me. Was it possible that Mrs. Inglethorp's mind was deranged? Had she some fantastic idea of demoniacal possession? And, if that were so, was it not also possible that she might have taken her own life?
I was about to expound these theories to Poirot, when his own words distracted me.

quote.s: "now to examine the coffee-cups!"
"My dear Poirot! What on earth is the good of that, now that we know\nabout the cocoa?"
"Oh, l l ! That miserable cocoa!"

div.p: cried Poirot flippantly.
He laughed with apparent enjoyment, raising his arms to heaven in mock despair, in what I could not but consider the worst possible taste.

quote.s:
"as Mrs. Inglethorp
took her coffee upstairs with her, I do not see what you expect to
find, unless you consider it likely that we shall discover a packet of
strychnine on the coffee tray!"

div.p: Poirot was sobered at once.

quote.s: "Ne\nvous f chez pas! Allow me to interest myself in my coffee-cups, and I\nwill respect your cocoa. There! Is it a bargain?"

div.p: He was so quaintly humorous that I was forced to laugh; and we went together to the drawing-room, where the coffee-cups and tray remained undisturbed as we had left them.
Poirot made me recapitulate the scene of the night before, listening very carefully, and verifying the position of the various cups.

quote.s:
"So Mrs. Cavendish stood by the tray and poured out. Yes. Then she came
across to the window where you sat with Mademoiselle Cynthia. Yes. Here
are the three cups. And the cup on the mantelpiece, half drunk, that
would be Mr. Lawrence Cavendish's. And the one on the tray?"
"John Cavendish's. I saw him put it down there."
"Good. One, two, three, four, five but where, then, is the cup of Mr.\nInglethorp?"
"He does not take coffee."
"Then all are accounted for. One moment, my friend."

div.p: With infinite care, he took a drop or two from the grounds in each cup, sealing them up in separate test tubes, tasting each in turn as he did so. His physiognomy underwent a curious change. An expression gathered there that I can only describe as half puzzled, and half relieved.

quote.s: "It is evident! I had an idea but clearly I\nwas mistaken. Yes, altogether I was mistaken. Yet it is strange. But no\nmatter!"

div.p: And, with a characteristic shrug, he dismissed whatever it was that was worrying him from his mind. I could have told him from the beginning that this obsession of his over the coffee was bound to end in a blind alley, but I restrained my tongue. After all, though he was old, Poirot had been a great man in his day.

quote.s: "You will breakfast with us, Monsieur Poirot?"

div.p: Poirot acquiesced. I observed John. Already he was almost restored to his normal self. The shock of the events of the last night had upset him temporarily, but his equable poise soon swung back to the normal. He was a man of very little imagination, in sharp contrast with his brother, who had, perhaps, too much.

Ever since the early hours of the morning, John had been hard at work, sending telegrams one of the first had gone to Evelyn Howard writing notices for the papers, and generally occupying himself with the melancholy duties that a death entails.

quote.s: "Do your investigations\npoint to my mother having died a natural death or or must we prepare\nourselves for the worst?"
"that you would do well\nnot to buoy yourself up with any false hopes. Can you tell me the views\nof the other members of the family?"
"My brother Lawrence is convinced that we are making a fuss over\nnothing. He says that everything points to its being a simple case of\nheart failure."
"And Mrs. Cavendish?"

div.p: A faint cloud passed over John's face.

quote.s: "I have not the least idea what my wife's views on the subject are."

div.p: The answer brought a momentary stiffness in its train. John broke the rather awkward silence by saying with a slight effort:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: John broke the rather awkward silence by saying
quote.s: "I told you, didn't I, that Mr. Inglethorp has returned?"

div.p: Poirot bent his head.

quote.s: "It's an awkward position for all of us. Of course one has to treat him\nas usual but, hang it all, one's gorge does rise at sitting down to eat\nwith a possible murderer!"

div.p: Poirot nodded sympathetically.

quote.s:
"I quite understand. It is a very difficult situation for you, Mr.
Cavendish. I would like to ask you one question. Mr. Inglethorp's
reason for not returning last night was, I believe, that he had
forgotten the latch-key. Is not that so?"
"Yes."
"I suppose you are quite sure that the latch-key was forgotten that\nhe did not take it after all?"
"I have no idea. I never thought of looking. We always keep it in the\nhall drawer. I'll go and see if it's there now."

div.p: Poirot held up his hand with a faint smile.

quote.s: "No, no, Mr. Cavendish, it is too late now. I am certain that you would\nfind it. If Mr. Inglethorp did take it, he has had ample time to\nreplace it by now."
"But do you think"
"I think nothing. If anyone had chanced to look this morning before his\nreturn, and seen it there, it would have been a valuable point in his\nfavour. That is all."

div.p: John looked perplexed.

quote.s: "I assure you that you need not\nlet it trouble you. Since you are so kind, let us go and have some\nbreakfast."

div.p: Everyone was assembled in the dining-room. Under the circumstances, we were naturally not a cheerful party. The reaction after a shock is always trying, and I think we were all suffering from it. Decorum and good breeding naturally enjoined that our demeanour should be much as usual, yet I could not help wondering if this self-control were really a matter of great difficulty. There were no red eyes, no signs of secretly indulged grief. I felt that I was right in my opinion that Dorcas was the person most affected by the personal side of the tragedy.

I pass over Alfred Inglethorp, who acted the bereaved widower in a manner that I felt to be disgusting in its hypocrisy. Did he know that we suspected him, I wondered. Surely he could not be unaware of the fact, conceal it as we would. Did he feel some secret stirring of fear, or was he confident that his crime would go unpunished? Surely the suspicion in the atmosphere must warn him that he was already a marked man.

But did everyone suspect him? What about Mrs. Cavendish? I watched her as she sat at the head of the table, graceful, composed, enigmatic. In her soft grey frock, with white ruffles at the wrists falling over her slender hands, she looked very beautiful. When she chose, however, her face could be sphinx-like in its inscrutability. She was very silent, hardly opening her lips, and yet in some queer way I felt that the great strength of her personality was dominating us all.
And little Cynthia? Did she suspect? She looked very tired and ill, I thought. The heaviness and languor of her manner were very marked. I asked her if she were feeling ill, and she answered frankly:

quote.s: "Yes, I've got the most beastly headache."
"It will revive you. It is unparalleled for the mal de t te."

div.p: He jumped up and took her cup.

quote.s: "No sugar,"

div.p: said Cynthia, watching him, as he picked up the sugar-tongs.

quote.s: "No sugar? You abandon it in the war-time, eh?"
"No, I never take it in coffee."
"Sacr !"

div.p: murmured Poirot to himself, as he brought back the replenished cup.

Only I heard him, and glancing up curiously at the little man I saw that his face was working with suppressed excitement, and his eyes were as green as a cat's. He had heard or seen something that had affected him strongly but what was it? I do not usually label myself as dense, but I must confess that nothing out of the ordinary had attracted _my_ attention.
In another moment, the door opened and Dorcas appeared.

quote.s: "Mr. Wells to see you, sir,"

div.p: she said to John.
I remembered the name as being that of the lawyer to whom Mrs. Inglethorp had written the night before.
John rose immediately.

quote.s: "Show him into my study."

div.p: Then he turned to us.

quote.s: "My mother's lawyer,"

div.p: he explained. And in a lower voice:

quote.s: "He is also Coroner you understand.\nPerhaps you would like to come with me?"

div.p: We acquiesced and followed him out of the room. John strode on ahead and I took the opportunity of whispering to Poirot:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: I took the opportunity of whispering to Poirot
quote.s: "There will be an inquest then?"

div.p: Poirot nodded absently. He seemed absorbed in thought; so much so that my curiosity was aroused.

quote.s: "What is it? You are not attending to what I say."
"It is true, my friend. I am much worried."
"Why?"
"Because Mademoiselle Cynthia does not take sugar in her coffee."
"What? You cannot be serious?"
"But I am most serious. Ah, there is something there that I do not\nunderstand. My instinct was right."
"What instinct?"
"The instinct that led me to insist on examining those coffee-cups.\nChut! no more now!"

div.p: We followed John into his study, and he closed the door behind us.
Mr. Wells was a pleasant man of middle-age, with keen eyes, and the typical lawyer's mouth. John introduced us both, and explained the reason of our presence.

quote.s: "that this is all strictly\nprivate. We are still hoping that there will turn out to be no need for\ninvestigation of any kind."
"I wish we could have\nspared you the pain and publicity of an inquest, but of course it's\nquite unavoidable in the absence of a doctor's certificate."
"Yes, I suppose so."
"Clever man, Bauerstein. Great authority on toxicology, I believe."
"Indeed,"

div.p: said John with a certain stiffness in his manner. Then he added rather hesitatingly:

quote.s: "Shall we have to appear as witnesses all of\nus, I mean?"
"You, of course and ah er Mr. er Inglethorp."

div.p: A slight pause ensued before the lawyer went on in his soothing manner:

quote.s: "Any other evidence will be simply confirmatory, a mere matter of\nform."
"I see."

div.p: A faint expression of relief swept over John's face. It puzzled me, for I saw no occasion for it.

quote.s: "I had\nthought of Friday. That will give us plenty of time for the doctor's\nreport. The post-mortem is to take place to-night, I believe?"
"Yes."
"Then that arrangement will suit you?"
"Perfectly."
"I need not tell you, my dear Cavendish, how distressed I am at this\nmost tragic affair."
"Can you give us no help in solving it, monsieur?"

div.p: interposed Poirot, speaking for the first time since we had entered the room.

quote.s: "Yes, we heard that Mrs. Inglethorp wrote to you last night. You should\nhave received the letter this morning."
"I did, but it contains no information. It is merely a note asking me\nto call upon her this morning, as she wanted my advice on a matter of\ngreat importance."
"She gave you no hint as to what that matter might be?"
"Unfortunately, no."
"That is a pity,"

div.p: said John.

quote.s: "A great pity,"

div.p: agreed Poirot gravely.
There was silence. Poirot remained lost in thought for a few minutes. Finally he turned to the lawyer again.

quote.s: "Mr. Wells, there is one thing I should like to ask you that is, if it\nis not against professional etiquette. In the event of Mrs.\nInglethorp's death, who would inherit her money?"

div.p: The lawyer hesitated a moment, and then replied:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: The lawyer hesitated a moment and then replied
quote.s: "The knowledge will be public property very soon, so if Mr. Cavendish\ndoes not object"
"Not at all,"

div.p: interpolated John.

quote.s:
"I do not see any reason why I should not answer your question. By her
last will, dated August of last year, after various unimportant
legacies to servants, etc., she gave her entire fortune to her stepson,
Mr. John Cavendish."
"Was not that pardon the question, Mr. Cavendish rather unfair to her\nother stepson, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish?"

"No, I do not think so. You see, under the terms of their father's
will, while John inherited the property, Lawrence, at his stepmother's
death, would come into a considerable sum of money. Mrs. Inglethorp
left her money to her elder stepson, knowing that he would have to keep
up Styles. It was, to my mind, a very fair and equitable distribution."

div.p: Poirot nodded thoughtfully.

quote.s: "I see. But I am right in saying, am I not, that by your English law\nthat will was automatically revoked when Mrs. Inglethorp remarried?"

div.p: Mr. Wells bowed his head.

quote.s: "As I was about to proceed, Monsieur Poirot, that document is now null\nand void."
"Hein!"

div.p: said Poirot. He reflected for a moment, and then asked:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He reflected for a moment and then asked
quote.s: "Was\nMrs. Inglethorp herself aware of that fact?"
"I do not know. She may have been."
"We were discussing the matter of\nwills being revoked by marriage only yesterday."
"Ah! One more question, Mr. Wells. You say"

div.p: her last will.'

quote.s: "Had Mrs.\nInglethorp, then, made several former wills?"
"She was given to changing her mind as to her\ntestamentary dispositions, now benefiting one, now another member of\nher family."

"that, unknown to you, she had made a new
will in favour of someone who was not, in any sense of the word, a
member of the family we will say Miss Howard, for instance would you be
surprised?"
"Not in the least."
"Ah!"

div.p: Poirot seemed to have exhausted his questions.
I drew close to him, while John and the lawyer were debating the question of going through Mrs. Inglethorp's papers.

quote.s: "Do you think Mrs. Inglethorp made a will leaving all her money to Miss\nHoward?"

div.p: I asked in a low voice, with some curiosity.
Poirot smiled.

quote.s: "No."
"Then why did you ask?"
"Hush!"

div.p: John Cavendish had turned to Poirot.

quote.s: "Will you come with us, Monsieur Poirot? We are going through my\nmother's papers. Mr. Inglethorp is quite willing to leave it entirely\nto Mr. Wells and myself."
"As\ntechnically, of course, he was entitled"

div.p: He did not finish the sentence.

quote.s: "and go up to her bedroom afterwards. She kept her most important\npapers in a purple despatch-case, which we must look through\ncarefully."
"it is quite possible that there may be a later\nwill than the one in my possession."
"There is a later will."

div.p: It was Poirot who spoke.
What?" John and the lawyer looked at him startled.

quote.s: "there was one."

div.p: What do you mean there was one? Where is it now?

quote.s: "Burnt!"

div.p: Burnt?

quote.s: "Yes. See here."

div.p: He took out the charred fragment we had found in the grate in Mrs. Inglethorp's room, and handed it to the lawyer with a brief explanation of when and where he had found it.
But possibly this is an old will?

quote.s: "I do not think so. In fact I am almost certain that it was made no\nearlier than yesterday afternoon."

div.p: What?" "Impossible!" broke simultaneously from both men.
Poirot turned to John.

quote.s: "If you will allow me to send for your gardener, I will prove it to\nyou."
"Oh, of course but I don't see"

div.p: Poirot raised his hand.

quote.s: "Do as I ask you. Afterwards you shall question as much as you please."
"Very well."

div.p: He rang the bell.
Dorcas answered it in due course.

quote.s: "Dorcas, will you tell Manning to come round and speak to me here."
"Yes, sir."

div.p: Dorcas withdrew.
We waited in a tense silence. Poirot alone seemed perfectly at his ease, and dusted a forgotten corner of the bookcase.
The clumping of hobnailed boots on the gravel outside proclaimed the approach of Manning. John looked questioningly at Poirot. The latter nodded.

quote.s: "this gentleman will put some questions to you\nwhich I want you to answer."
"Yessir,"

div.p: mumbled Manning.
Poirot stepped forward briskly. Manning's eye swept over him with a faint contempt.

quote.s: "You were planting a bed of begonias round by the south side of the\nhouse yesterday afternoon, were you not, Manning?"
"Yes, sir, me and Willum."
"And Mrs. Inglethorp came to the window and called you, did she not?"
"Yes, sir, she did."
"Tell me in your own words exactly what happened after that."
"Well, sir, nothing much. She just told Willum to go on his bicycle\ndown to the village, and bring back a form of will, or such-like I\ndon't know what exactly she wrote it down for him."
"Well?"
"Well, he did, sir."
"And what happened next?"
"We went on with the begonias, sir."
"Did not Mrs. Inglethorp call you again?"
"Yes, sir, both me and Willum, she called."
"And then?"
"She made us come right in, and sign our names at the bottom of a long\npaper under where she'd signed."
"Did you see anything of what was written above her signature?"

div.p: asked Poirot sharply.

quote.s: "No, sir, there was a bit of blotting paper over that part."
"And you signed where she told you?"
"Yes, sir, first me and then Willum."
"What did she do with it afterwards?"
"Well, sir, she slipped it into a long envelope, and put it inside a\nsort of purple box that was standing on the desk."
"What time was it when she first called you?"
"About four, I should say, sir."
"Not earlier? Couldn't it have been about half-past three?"
"No, I shouldn't say so, sir. It would be more likely to be a bit after\nfour not before it."
"Thank you, Manning, that will do,"

div.p: said Poirot pleasantly.
The gardener glanced at his master, who nodded, whereupon Manning lifted a finger to his forehead with a low mumble, and backed cautiously out of the window.
We all looked at each other.

quote.s: "What an extraordinary coincidence."
"How a coincidence?"
"That my mother should have made a will on the very day of her death!"

div.p: Mr. Wells cleared his throat and remarked drily:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Mr Wells cleared his throat and remarked
quote.s: "Are you so sure it is a coincidence, Cavendish?"
"What do you mean?"
"Your mother, you tell me, had a violent quarrel with someone yesterday\nafternoon"
"What do you mean?"

div.p: cried John again. There was a tremor in his voice, and he had gone very pale.

quote.s:
"In consequence of that quarrel, your mother very suddenly and
hurriedly makes a new will. The contents of that will we shall never
know. She told no one of its provisions. This morning, no doubt, she
would have consulted me on the subject but she had no chance. The will
disappears, and she takes its secret with her to her grave. Cavendish,
I much fear there is no coincidence there. Monsieur Poirot, I am sure
you agree with me that the facts are very suggestive."

"we are most grateful to
Monsieur Poirot for elucidating the matter. But for him, we should
never have known of this will. I suppose, I may not ask you, monsieur,
what first led you to suspect the fact?"

div.p: Poirot smiled and answered:

quote.s: "A scribbled over old envelope, and a freshly planted bed of begonias."

div.p: John, I think, would have pressed his questions further, but at that moment the loud purr of a motor was audible, and we all turned to the window as it swept past.

quote.s: "Excuse me, Wells."

div.p: He went hurriedly out into the hall.
Poirot looked inquiringly at me.

quote.s: "Miss Howard,"

div.p: I explained.

quote.s: "Ah, I am glad she has come. There is a woman with a head and a heart\ntoo, Hastings. Though the good God gave her no beauty!"

div.p: I followed John's example, and went out into the hall, where Miss Howard was endeavouring to extricate herself from the voluminous mass of veils that enveloped her head. As her eyes fell on me, a sudden pang of guilt shot through me. This was the woman who had warned me so earnestly, and to whose warning I had, alas, paid no heed! How soon, and how contemptuously, I had dismissed it from my mind. Now that she had been proved justified in so tragic a manner, I felt ashamed. She had known Alfred Inglethorp only too well. I wondered whether, if she had remained at Styles, the tragedy would have taken place, or would the man have feared her watchful eyes?

I was relieved when she shook me by the hand, with her well remembered painful grip. The eyes that met mine were sad, but not reproachful; that she had been crying bitterly, I could tell by the redness of her eyelids, but her manner was unchanged from its old gruffness.

quote.s: "Started the moment I got the wire. Just come off night duty. Hired\ncar. Quickest way to get here."
"Have you had anything to eat this morning, Evie?"

div.p: asked John.

quote.s: "No."
"I thought not. Come along, breakfast's not cleared away yet, and\nthey'll make you some fresh tea."

div.p: He turned to me.

quote.s: "Look after her,\nHastings, will you? Wells is waiting for me. Oh, here's Monsieur\nPoirot. He's helping us, you know, Evie."

div.p: Miss Howard shook hands with Poirot, but glanced suspiciously over her shoulder at John.

quote.s: "What do you mean helping us?"
"Helping us to investigate."
"Nothing to investigate. Have they taken him to prison yet?"
"Taken who to prison?"
"Who? Alfred Inglethorp, of course!"
"My dear Evie, do be careful. Lawrence is of the opinion that my mother\ndied from heart seizure."
"Of course Alfred\nInglethorp murdered poor Emily as I always told you he would."
"My dear Evie, don't shout so. Whatever we may think or suspect, it is\nbetter to say as little as possible for the present. The inquest isn't\nuntil Friday."
"Not until fiddlesticks!"

div.p: The snort Miss Howard gave was truly magnificent.

quote.s: "You're all off your heads. The man will be out of the\ncountry by then. If he's any sense, he won't stay here tamely and wait\nto be hanged."

div.p: John Cavendish looked at her helplessly.

quote.s: "You ought to be ashamed of yourself, John Cavendish."
"Dash it all, Evie, I can't haul him down to the local police station\nby the scruff of his neck."
"Well, you might do something. Find out how he did it. He's a crafty\nbeggar. Dare say he soaked fly papers. Ask cook if she's missed any."

div.p: It occurred to me very forcibly at that moment that to harbour Miss Howard and Alfred Inglethorp under the same roof, and keep the peace between them, was likely to prove a Herculean task, and I did not envy John. I could see by the expression of his face that he fully appreciated the difficulty of the position. For the moment, he sought refuge in retreat, and left the room precipitately.
Dorcas brought in fresh tea. As she left the room, Poirot came over from the window where he had been standing, and sat down facing Miss Howard.

quote.s: "I want to ask you something."
"Ask away,"

div.p: said the lady, eyeing him with some disfavour.

quote.s: "I want to be able to count upon your help."
"Hanging's too good for him. Ought to be drawn and quartered, like in\ngood old times."
"for I, too, want to hang the\ncriminal."
"Alfred Inglethorp?"
"Him, or another."

"No question of another. Poor Emily was never murdered until he came
along. I don't say she wasn't surrounded by sharks she was. But it was
only her purse they were after. Her life was safe enough. But along
comes Mr. Alfred Inglethorp and within two months hey presto!"
"if Mr.\nInglethorp is the man, he shall not escape me. On my honour, I will\nhang him as high as Haman!"
"That's better,"

div.p: said Miss Howard more enthusiastically.

quote.s: "But I must ask you to trust me. Now your help may be very valuable to\nme. I will tell you why. Because, in all this house of mourning, yours\nare the only eyes that have wept."

div.p: Miss Howard blinked, and a new note crept into the gruffness of her voice.

quote.s:
"If you mean that I was fond of her yes, I was. You know, Emily was a
selfish old woman in her way. She was very generous, but she always
wanted a return. She never let people forget what she had done for
them and, that way she missed love. Don't think she ever realized it,
though, or felt the lack of it. Hope not, anyway. I was on a different
footing. I took my stand from the first."

div.p: So many pounds a year I'm worth to you. Well and good. But not a penny piece besides not a pair of gloves, nor a theatre ticket.'

quote.s:
"She didn't understand was very
offended sometimes. Said I was foolishly proud. It wasn't that but I
couldn't explain. Anyway, I kept my self-respect. And so, out of the
whole bunch, I was the only one who could allow myself to be fond of
her. I watched over her. I guarded her from the lot of them, and then a
glib-tongued scoundrel comes along, and pooh! all my years of devotion
go for nothing."

div.p: Poirot nodded sympathetically.

quote.s: "I understand, mademoiselle, I understand all you feel. It is most\nnatural. You think that we are lukewarm that we lack fire and\nenergy but trust me, it is not so."

div.p: John stuck his head in at this juncture, and invited us both to come up to Mrs. Inglethorp's room, as he and Mr. Wells had finished looking through the desk in the boudoir.
As we went up the stairs, John looked back to the dining-room door, and lowered his voice confidentially:

quote.s: "Look here, what's going to happen when these two meet?"

div.p: I shook my head helplessly.

quote.s: "I've told Mary to keep them apart if she can."
"Will she be able to do so?"
"The Lord only knows. There's one thing, Inglethorp himself won't be\ntoo keen on meeting her."
"You've got the keys still, haven't you, Poirot?"

div.p: I asked, as we reached the door of the locked room.
Taking the keys from Poirot, John unlocked it, and we all passed in. The lawyer went straight to the desk, and John followed him.

quote.s: "My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I\nbelieve,"

div.p: he said.
Poirot drew out the small bunch of keys.

quote.s: "Permit me. I locked it, out of precaution, this morning."
"But it's not locked now."
"Impossible!"

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: John lifted the lid as he spoke
quote.s: "See."

div.p: And John lifted the lid as he spoke.

quote.s: "Eh voil une affaire! This lock has been forced."

div.p: What?
Poirot laid down the case again.
But who forced it? Why should they? When? But the door was locked? These exclamations burst from us disjointedly.
Poirot answered them categorically almost mechanically.

quote.s: "Who? That is the question. Why? Ah, if I only knew. When? Since I was\nhere an hour ago. As to the door being locked, it is a very ordinary\nlock. Probably any other of the doorkeys in this passage would fit it."

div.p: We stared at one another blankly. Poirot had walked over to the mantelpiece. He was outwardly calm, but I noticed his hands, which from long force of habit were mechanically straightening the spill vases on the mantelpiece, were shaking violently.

quote.s:
"There was something in
that case some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still
enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital
to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its
significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk,
of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it,
thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have
been something of great importance."

div.p: But what was it?

quote.s:
"miserable animal that I am! I guessed nothing! I have
behaved like an imbecile! I should never have left that case here. I
should have carried it away with me. Ah, triple pig! And now it is
gone. It is destroyed but is it destroyed? Is there not yet a chance we
must leave no stone unturned"

div.p: He rushed like a madman from the room, and I followed him as soon as I had sufficiently recovered my wits. But, by the time I had reached the top of the stairs, he was out of sight.
Mary Cavendish was standing where the staircase branched, staring down into the hall in the direction in which he had disappeared.

quote.s: "What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings?\nHe has just rushed past me like a mad bull."
"He's rather upset about something,"

div.p: I remarked feebly. I really did not know how much Poirot would wish me to disclose. As I saw a faint smile gather on Mrs. Cavendish's expressive mouth, I endeavoured to try and turn the conversation by saying:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: I endeavoured to try and turn the conversation by saying
quote.s: "They haven't met yet, have they?"
"Who?"
"Mr. Inglethorp and Miss Howard."

div.p: She looked at me in rather a disconcerting manner.

quote.s: "Do you think it would be such a disaster if they did meet?"
"Well, don't you?"

div.p: I said, rather taken aback.

quote.s: "No."

div.p: She was smiling in her quiet way.

quote.s: "I should like to see a good\nflare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so\nmuch, and saying so little."
"He's anxious to keep them apart."
"Oh, John!"

div.p: Something in her tone fired me, and I blurted out:

quote.s: "Old John's an awfully good sort."

div.p: She studied me curiously for a minute or two, and then said, to my great surprise:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: She studied me curiously for a minute or two and then said
quote.s: "You are loyal to your friend. I like you for that."
"Aren't you my friend too?"
"I am a very bad friend."
"Why do you say that?"
"Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget\nall about them the next."

div.p: I don't know what impelled me, but I was nettled, and I said foolishly and not in the best of taste:

quote.s: "Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!"

div.p: Instantly I regretted my words. Her face stiffened. I had the impression of a steel curtain coming down and blotting out the real woman. Without a word, she turned and went swiftly up the stairs, whilst I stood like an idiot gaping after her.

I was recalled to other matters by a frightful row going on below. I could hear Poirot shouting and expounding. I was vexed to think that my diplomacy had been in vain. The little man appeared to be taking the whole house into his confidence, a proceeding of which I, for one, doubted the wisdom. Once again I could not help regretting that my friend was so prone to lose his head in moments of excitement. I stepped briskly down the stairs. The sight of me calmed Poirot almost immediately. I drew him aside.

quote.s: "is this wise? Surely you don't want the\nwhole house to know of this occurrence? You are actually playing into\nthe criminal's hands."
"You think so, Hastings?"
"I am sure of it."
"Well, well, my friend, I will be guided by you."
"Good. Although, unfortunately, it is a little too late now."
"Sure."

div.p: He looked so crestfallen and abashed that I felt quite sorry, though I still thought my rebuke a just and wise one.

quote.s: "let us go, mon ami."
"You have finished here?"
"For the moment, yes. You will walk back with me to the village?"
"Willingly."

div.p: He picked up his little suit-case, and we went out through the open window in the drawing-room. Cynthia Murdoch was just coming in, and Poirot stood aside to let her pass.

quote.s: "Excuse me, mademoiselle, one minute."
"Yes?"

div.p: she turned inquiringly.

quote.s: "Did you ever make up Mrs. Inglethorp's medicines?"

div.p: A slight flush rose in her face, as she answered rather constrainedly:

quote.s: "No."
"Only her powders?"

div.p: The flush deepened as Cynthia replied:

quote.s: "Oh, yes, I did make up some sleeping powders for her once."
"These?"

div.p: Poirot produced the empty box which had contained powders.
She nodded.

quote.s: "Can you tell me what they were? Sulphonal? Veronal?"
"No, they were bromide powders."
"Ah! Thank you, mademoiselle; good morning."

div.p: As we walked briskly away from the house, I glanced at him more than once. I had often before noticed that, if anything excited him, his eyes turned green like a cat's. They were shining like emeralds now.

quote.s: "I have a little idea, a very\nstrange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet it fits in."

div.p: I shrugged my shoulders. I privately thought that Poirot was rather too much given to these fantastic ideas. In this case, surely, the truth was only too plain and apparent.

quote.s: "Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it\nmyself."

div.p: Poirot did not appear to be listening to me.

quote.s: "Mr. Wells told me\nas we were going upstairs."
"What was it?"

"Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs.
Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred
Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged.
It came quite as a surprise to Wells and to John Cavendish also. It was
written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the
servants not Dorcas."
"Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?"
"He says not."
"All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled\nwords on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made\nyesterday afternoon?"

div.p: Poirot smiled.

quote.s: "Mon ami, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the\nfact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?"
"Yes, often. I suppose everyone has."

"Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or
twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to
see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You
will notice that the word possessed' is spelt first with one s' and
subsequently with two correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it
in a sentence, thus:"

div.p: I am possessed.'

quote.s:
"Now, what did that tell me? It
told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word possessed' that
afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh
in my mind, the possibility of a will (a document almost certain to
contain that word) occurred to me at once. This possibility was
confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the
boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several
traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine
for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy
deposit."

"I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had
been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that
on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they had
been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly
both of the gardeners for there were two sets of footprints in the
bed had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished
to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window,
and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite
convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two
gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right
in my supposition."
"I must confess\nthat the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite\nerroneous."

div.p: He smiled.

quote.s: "You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good\nservant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most\nlikely."
"Another point how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had\nbeen lost?"

"I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You
observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That
suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy
key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would
at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what
was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to
the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the
lock of the despatch-case."
"Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt."

div.p: Poirot looked at me curiously.

quote.s: "You are very sure of his guilt?"
"Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more\nclearly."
"there are several points in\nhis favour."
"Oh, come now!"
"Yes."
"I see only one."
"And that?"
"That he was not in the house last night."
"Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to\nmy mind tells against him."
"How is that?"

"Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last
night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His
excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two
possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a
reason of his own for his absence."
"And that reason?"

div.p: I asked sceptically.
Poirot shrugged his shoulders.

quote.s: "How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp,\nI should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel but that does not of necessity\nmake him a murderer."

div.p: I shook my head, unconvinced.

quote.s:
"Well, let us leave it. Time will
show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the
case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom
were bolted on the inside?"
"One must look at it logically."
"true."

"I should put it this way. The doors were bolted our own eyes have
told us that yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and
the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone
entered the room. You agree so far?"
"Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed."

"as the person who entered did not do so by
the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have
been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens
the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would
naturally open the door to her own husband."

div.p: Poirot shook his head.

quote.s: "Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room a most\nunusual proceeding on her part she had had a most violent quarrel with\nhim that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit."
"But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs.\nInglethorp herself?"
"There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door\ninto the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards\nmorning, and bolted it then."
"Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?"
"No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another\nfeature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard\nbetween Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?"

"That is as enigmatical as
ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and
reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was
certainly not her affair."
"Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to\ndo."
"Still, it is unimportant, and\nneed not be taken into account."

div.p: A groan burst from Poirot.

quote.s: "What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If\nthe fact will not fit the theory let the theory go."
"Well, we shall see,"

div.p: I said, nettled.

quote.s: "Yes, we shall see."

div.p: We had reached Leastways Cottage, and Poirot ushered me upstairs to his own room. He offered me one of the tiny Russian cigarettes he himself occasionally smoked. I was amused to notice that he stowed away the used matches most carefully in a little china pot. My momentary annoyance vanished.
Poirot had placed our two chairs in front of the open window which commanded a view of the village street. The fresh air blew in warm and pleasant. It was going to be a hot day.

Suddenly my attention was arrested by a weedy looking young man rushing down the street at a great pace. It was the expression on his face that was extraordinary a curious mingling of terror and agitation.

quote.s: "Look, Poirot!"

div.p: I said.
He leant forward.

quote.s: "It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is\ncoming here."

div.p: The young man came to a halt before Leastways Cottage, and, after hesitating a moment, pounded vigorously at the door.

quote.s: "I come."

div.p: Motioning to me to follow him, he ran swiftly down the stairs and opened the door. Mr. Mace began at once.

quote.s: "Oh, Mr. Poirot, I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that\nyou'd just come back from the Hall?"
"Yes, we have."

div.p: The young man moistened his dry lips. His face was working curiously.

quote.s: "It's all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly.\nThey do say"

div.p: he lowered his voice cautiously

quote.s: "that it's poison?"

div.p: Poirot's face remained quite impassive.

quote.s: "Only the doctors can tell us that, Mr. Mace."
"Yes, exactly of course"

div.p: The young man hesitated, and then his agitation was too much for him. He clutched Poirot by the arm, and sank his voice to a whisper:

quote.s: "Just tell me this, Mr. Poirot, it isn't it\nisn't strychnine, is it?"

div.p: I hardly heard what Poirot replied. Something evidently of a non-committal nature. The young man departed, and as he closed the door Poirot's eyes met mine.

quote.s: "He will have evidence to give at the\ninquest."

div.p: We went slowly upstairs again. I was opening my lips, when Poirot stopped me with a gesture of his hand.

quote.s: "Not now, not now, mon ami. I have need of reflection. My mind is in\nsome disorder which is not well."

div.p: For about ten minutes he sat in dead silence, perfectly still, except for several expressive motions of his eyebrows, and all the time his eyes grew steadily greener. At last he heaved a deep sigh.

quote.s:
"It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and
classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear
yet no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles me. Me,
Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance."
"And what are they?"
"The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very\nimportant."
"Poirot, you're pulling my\nleg!"
"Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not\nforget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!"
"And the second point?"

div.p: I asked.

quote.s: "The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar\nclothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses."
"Poirot, I cannot believe you are serious."
"I am absolutely serious, my friend."
"But this is childish!"
"No, it is very momentous."
"And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder\nagainst Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?"
"I should not allow it!"
"You would not allow it?"
"No."

div.p: I looked at the extraordinary little man, divided between annoyance and amusement. He was so tremendously sure of himself. As though he read my thoughts, he nodded gently.

quote.s: "Oh, yes, mon ami, I would do what I say."

div.p: He got up and laid his hand on my shoulder. His physiognomy underwent a complete change. Tears came into his eyes.

quote.s: "In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs.\nInglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved no. But she was\nvery good to us Belgians I owe her a debt."

div.p: I endeavoured to interrupt, but Poirot swept on.
Let me tell you this, Hastings. She would never forgive me if I let Alfred Inglethorp, her husband, be arrested _now_ when a word from me could save him!
div.head: CHAPTER VI.
THE INQUEST
div.p: In the interval before the inquest, Poirot was unfailing in his activity. Twice he was closeted with Mr. Wells. He also took long walks into the country. I rather resented his not taking me into his confidence, the more so as I could not in the least guess what he was driving at.

It occurred to me that he might have been making inquiries at Raikes's farm; so, finding him out when I called at Leastways Cottage on Wednesday evening, I walked over there by the fields, hoping to meet him. But there was no sign of him, and I hesitated to go right up to the farm itself. As I walked away, I met an aged rustic, who leered at me cunningly.

quote.s: "You'm from the Hall, bain't you?"

div.p: he asked.

quote.s: "Yes. I'm looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked\nthis way."
"A little chap? As waves his hands when he talks? One of them Belgies\nfrom the village?"
quote.rs: One of them Belgies\nfrom the village

quote.s: "He has been here, then?"
"Oh, ay, he's been here, right enough. More'n once too. Friend of\nyours, is he? Ah, you gentlemen from the Hall you'm a pretty lot!"

div.p: And he leered more jocosely than ever.

quote.s: "Why, do the gentlemen from the Hall come here often?"

div.p: I asked, as carelessly as I could.
He winked at me knowingly.

quote.s: "One does, mister. Naming no names, mind. And a very liberal\ngentleman too! Oh, thank you, sir, I'm sure."

div.p: I walked on sharply. Evelyn Howard had been right then, and I experienced a sharp twinge of disgust, as I thought of Alfred Inglethorp's liberality with another woman's money. Had that piquant gipsy face been at the bottom of the crime, or was it the baser mainspring of money? Probably a judicious mixture of both.

On one point, Poirot seemed to have a curious obsession. He once or twice observed to me that he thought Dorcas must have made an error in fixing the time of the quarrel. He suggested to her repeatedly that it was four-thirty, and not four o'clock when she had heard the voices.
But Dorcas was unshaken. Quite an hour, or even more, had elapsed between the time when she had heard the voices and five o'clock, when she had taken tea to her mistress.
The inquest was held on Friday at the Stylites Arms in the village. Poirot and I sat together, not being required to give evidence.
The preliminaries were gone through. The jury viewed the body, and John Cavendish gave evidence of identification.
Further questioned, he described his awakening in the early hours of the morning, and the circumstances of his mother's death.

The medical evidence was next taken. There was a breathless hush, and every eye was fixed on the famous London specialist, who was known to be one of the greatest authorities of the day on the subject of toxicology.

In a few brief words, he summed up the result of the post-mortem. Shorn of its medical phraseology and technicalities, it amounted to the fact that Mrs. Inglethorp had met her death as the result of strychnine poisoning. Judging from the quantity recovered, she must have taken not less than three-quarters of a grain of strychnine, but probably one grain or slightly over.

quote.s: "Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?"

div.p: asked the Coroner.

quote.s: "I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for\ndomestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions\nplaced on its sale."
"Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison\nwas administered?"
"No."
"You arrived at Styles before Dr. Wilkins, I believe?"
"That is so. The motor met me just outside the lodge gates, and I\nhurried there as fast as I could."
"Will you relate to us exactly what happened next?"
"I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical\ntetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:"

div.p: Alfred Alfred '

quote.s: "Could the strychnine have been administered in Mrs. Inglethorp's\nafter-dinner coffee which was taken to her by her husband?"

"Possibly, but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in its action. The
symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed. It
is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to
have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the
coffee after dinner about eight o'clock, whereas the symptoms did not
manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the
face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the
evening."
"Mrs. Inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the\nmiddle of the night. Could the strychnine have been administered in\nthat?"
"No, I myself took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and\nhad it analysed. There was no strychnine present."

div.p: I heard Poirot chuckle softly beside me.

quote.s: "How did you know?"

div.p: I whispered.

quote.s: "Listen."
"that I would have been\nconsiderably surprised at any other result."
"Why?"

"Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste. It can be
detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and can only be
disguised by some strongly flavoured substance. Cocoa would be quite
powerless to mask it."

div.p: One of the jury wanted to know if the same objection applied to coffee.

quote.s: "No. Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover\nthe taste of strychnine."
"Then you consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the\ncoffee, but that for some unknown reason its action was delayed."
"Yes, but, the cup being completely smashed, there is no possibility of\nanalyzing its contents."

div.p: This concluded Dr. Bauerstein's evidence. Dr. Wilkins corroborated it on all points. Sounded as to the possibility of suicide, he repudiated it utterly. The deceased, he said, suffered from a weak heart, but otherwise enjoyed perfect health, and was of a cheerful and well-balanced disposition. She would be one of the last people to take her own life.
Lawrence Cavendish was next called. His evidence was quite unimportant, being a mere repetition of that of his brother. Just as he was about to step down, he paused, and said rather hesitatingly:

quote.s: "I should like to make a suggestion if I may?"

div.p: He glanced deprecatingly at the Coroner, who replied briskly:

quote.s: "Certainly, Mr. Cavendish, we are here to arrive at the truth of this\nmatter, and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation."
"Of course I may be\nquite wrong, but it still seems to me that my mother's death might be\naccounted for by natural means."
"How do you make that out, Mr. Cavendish?"
"My mother, at the time of her death, and for some time before it, was\ntaking a tonic containing strychnine."
"Ah!"

div.p: said the Coroner.
The jury looked up, interested.

quote.s:
"that there have been cases where the
cumulative effect of a drug, administered for some time, has ended by
causing death. Also, is it not possible that she may have taken an
overdose of her medicine by accident?"
"This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at\nthe time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish."

div.p: Dr. Wilkins was recalled and ridiculed the idea.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Dr Wilkins was recalled and ridiculed
quote.s:
"What Mr. Cavendish suggests is quite impossible. Any doctor would tell
you the same. Strychnine is, in a certain sense, a cumulative poison,
but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in
this way. There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms
which would at once have attracted my attention. The whole thing is
absurd."
"And the second suggestion? That Mrs. Inglethorp may have inadvertently\ntaken an overdose?"

"Three, or even four doses, would not have resulted in death. Mrs.
Inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a
time, as she dealt with Coot's, the Cash Chemists in Tadminster. She
would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the
amount of strychnine found at the post-mortem."
"Then you consider that we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any\nway instrumental in causing her death?"
"Certainly. The supposition is ridiculous."

div.p: The same juryman who had interrupted before here suggested that the chemist who made up the medicine might have committed an error.

quote.s: "That, of course, is always possible,"

div.p: replied the doctor.

But Dorcas, who was the next witness called, dispelled even that possibility. The medicine had not been newly made up. On the contrary, Mrs. Inglethorp had taken the last dose on the day of her death.

So the question of the tonic was finally abandoned, and the Coroner proceeded with his task. Having elicited from Dorcas how she had been awakened by the violent ringing of her mistress's bell, and had subsequently roused the household, he passed to the subject of the quarrel on the preceding afternoon.
Dorcas's evidence on this point was substantially what Poirot and I had already heard, so I will not repeat it here.

The next witness was Mary Cavendish. She stood very upright, and spoke in a low, clear, and perfectly composed voice. In answer to the Coroner's question, she told how, her alarm clock having aroused her at four-thirty as usual, she was dressing, when she was startled by the sound of something heavy falling.

quote.s: "That would have been the table by the bed?"

div.p: commented the Coroner.

quote.s: "and listened. In a few minutes a\nbell rang violently. Dorcas came running down and woke my husband, and\nwe all went to my mother-in-law's room, but it was locked"

div.p: The Coroner interrupted her.

quote.s:
"I really do not think we need trouble you further on that point. We
know all that can be known of the subsequent happenings. But I should
be obliged if you would tell us all you overheard of the quarrel the
day before."
"She is gaining time!"
"that you were\nsitting reading on the bench just outside the long window of the\nboudoir. That is so, is it not?"

div.p: There was a faint insolence in her voice. She raised her hand and adjusted the ruffle of lace at her neck, turning her head a little as she did so. And quite spontaneously the thought flashed across my mind: This was news to me and glancing sideways at Poirot, I fancied that it was news to him as well.
There was the faintest pause, the mere hesitation of a moment, before she answered:

quote.s: "Yes, that is so."
"And the boudoir window was open, was it not?"

div.p: Surely her face grew a little paler as she answered:

quote.s: "Yes."
"Then you cannot have failed to hear the voices inside, especially as\nthey were raised in anger. In fact, they would be more audible where\nyou were than in the hall."
"Possibly."
"Will you repeat to us what you overheard of the quarrel?"
"I really do not remember hearing anything."
"Do you mean to say you did not hear voices?"
"Oh, yes, I heard the voices, but I did not hear what they said."

div.p: A faint spot of colour came into her cheek.

quote.s: "I am not in the habit of\nlistening to private conversations."

div.p: The Coroner persisted.

quote.s: "And you remember nothing at all? Nothing, Mrs. Cavendish? Not one\nstray word or phrase to make you realize that it was a private\nconversation?"

div.p: She paused, and seemed to reflect, still outwardly as calm as ever.

quote.s: "Yes; I remember. Mrs. Inglethorp said something I do not remember\nexactly what about causing scandal between husband and wife."
"Ah!"

div.p: the Coroner leant back satisfied.

quote.s:
"That corresponds with what
Dorcas heard. But excuse me, Mrs. Cavendish, although you realized it
was a private conversation, you did not move away? You remained where
you were?"

div.p: I caught the momentary gleam of her tawny eyes as she raised them. I felt certain that at that moment she would willingly have torn the little lawyer, with his insinuations, into pieces, but she replied quietly enough:

quote.s: "No. I was very comfortable where I was. I fixed my mind on my book."
"And that is all you can tell us?"
"That is all."

div.p: The examination was over, though I doubted if the Coroner was entirely satisfied with it. I think he suspected that Mary Cavendish could tell more if she chose.
Amy Hill, shop assistant, was next called, and deposed to having sold a will form on the afternoon of the 17th to William Earl, under-gardener at Styles.
William Earl and Manning succeeded her, and testified to witnessing a document. Manning fixed the time at about four-thirty, William was of the opinion that it was rather earlier.
Cynthia Murdoch came next. She had, however, little to tell. She had known nothing of the tragedy, until awakened by Mrs. Cavendish.

quote.s: "You did not hear the table fall?"
"No. I was fast asleep."

div.p: The Coroner smiled.

quote.s: "Thank you,\nMiss Murdoch, that is all."
"Miss Howard."

div.p: Miss Howard produced the letter written to her by Mrs. Inglethorp on the evening of the 17th. Poirot and I had, of course already seen it. It added nothing to our knowledge of the tragedy. The following is a facsimile:
div.head: STYLES COURT
ESSEX
div.p: hand written note:

July 17th My dear Evelyn Can we not bury the hachet? I have found it hard to forgive the things you said against my dear husband but I am an old woman & very fond of you Yours affectionately, Emily Inglethorpe
It was handed to the jury who scrutinized it attentively.

quote.s: "There is no mention of any of the events of that afternoon."
"It shows\nclearly enough that my poor old friend had just found out she'd been\nmade a fool of!"
"It says nothing of the kind in the letter,"

div.p: the Coroner pointed out.

quote.s:
"No, because Emily never could bear to put herself in the wrong. But
I know her. She wanted me back. But she wasn't going to own that I'd
been right. She went round about. Most people do. Don't believe in it
myself."

div.p: Mr. Wells smiled faintly. So, I noticed, did several of the jury. Miss Howard was obviously quite a public character.

quote.s: "Talk talk talk!\nWhen all the time we know perfectly well"

div.p: The Coroner interrupted her in an agony of apprehension:

quote.s: "Thank you, Miss Howard, that is all."

div.p: I fancy he breathed a sigh of relief when she complied.
Then came the sensation of the day. The Coroner called Albert Mace, chemist's assistant.

It was our agitated young man of the pale face. In answer to the Coroner's questions, he explained that he was a qualified pharmacist, but had only recently come to this particular shop, as the assistant formerly there had just been called up for the army.
These preliminaries completed, the Coroner proceeded to business.

quote.s: "Mr. Mace, have you lately sold strychnine to any unauthorized person?"
"Yes, sir."
"When was this?"
"Last Monday night."
"Monday? Not Tuesday?"
"No, sir, Monday, the 16th."
"Will you tell us to whom you sold it?"

div.p: You could have heard a pin drop.

quote.s: "Yes, sir. It was to Mr. Inglethorp."

div.p: Every eye turned simultaneously to where Alfred Inglethorp was sitting, impassive and wooden. He started slightly, as the damning words fell from the young man's lips. I half thought he was going to rise from his chair, but he remained seated, although a remarkably well acted expression of astonishment rose on his face.

quote.s: "You are sure of what you say?"

div.p: asked the Coroner sternly.

quote.s: "Quite sure, sir."
"Are you in the habit of selling strychnine indiscriminately over the\ncounter?"

div.p: The wretched young man wilted visibly under the Coroner's frown.

quote.s: "Oh, no, sir of course not. But, seeing it was Mr. Inglethorp of the\nHall, I thought there was no harm in it. He said it was to poison a\ndog."

div.p: Inwardly I sympathized. It was only human nature to endeavour to please The Hall" especially when it might result in custom being transferred from Coot's to the local establishment.

quote.s: "Is it not customary for anyone purchasing poison to sign a book?"
"Yes, sir, Mr. Inglethorp did so."
"Have you got the book here?"
"Yes, sir."

div.p: It was produced; and, with a few words of stern censure, the Coroner dismissed the wretched Mr. Mace.
Then, amidst a breathless silence, Alfred Inglethorp was called. Did he realize, I wondered, how closely the halter was being drawn around his neck?
The Coroner went straight to the point.

quote.s: "On Monday evening last, did you purchase strychnine for the purpose of\npoisoning a dog?"

div.p: Inglethorp replied with perfect calmness:

quote.s: "No, I did not. There is no dog at Styles, except an outdoor sheepdog,\nwhich is in perfect health."
"You deny absolutely having purchased strychnine from Albert Mace on\nMonday last?"
"I do."
"Do you also deny this?"

div.p: The Coroner handed him the register in which his signature was inscribed.

quote.s: "Certainly I do. The hand-writing is quite different from mine. I will\nshow you."

div.p: He took an old envelope out of his pocket, and wrote his name on it, handing it to the jury. It was certainly utterly dissimilar.

quote.s: "Then what is your explanation of Mr. Mace's statement?"

div.p: Alfred Inglethorp replied imperturbably:

quote.s: "Mr. Mace must have been mistaken."

div.p: The Coroner hesitated for a moment, and then said:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: The Coroner hesitated for a moment and then said
quote.s: "Mr. Inglethorp, as a mere matter of form, would you mind telling us\nwhere you were on the evening of Monday, July 16th?"
"Really I cannot remember."
"Think\nagain."

div.p: Inglethorp shook his head.

quote.s: "I cannot tell you. I have an idea that I was out walking."
"In what direction?"
"I really can't remember."

div.p: The Coroner's face grew graver.

quote.s: "Were you in company with anyone?"
"No."
"Did you meet anyone on your walk?"
"No."
"I am to take it then that\nyou decline to say where you were at the time that Mr. Mace positively\nrecognized you as entering the shop to purchase strychnine?"
"If you like to take it that way, yes."
"Be careful, Mr. Inglethorp."

div.p: Poirot was fidgeting nervously.

quote.s: "Does this imbecile of a man want to be\narrested?"

div.p: Inglethorp was indeed creating a bad impression. His futile denials would not have convinced a child. The Coroner, however, passed briskly to the next point, and Poirot drew a deep breath of relief.

quote.s: "You had a discussion with your wife on Tuesday afternoon?"
"you have been misinformed.\nI had no quarrel with my dear wife. The whole story is absolutely\nuntrue. I was absent from the house the entire afternoon."
"Have you anyone who can testify to that?"
"You have my word,"

div.p: said Inglethorp haughtily.
The Coroner did not trouble to reply.

quote.s: "There are two witnesses who will swear to having heard your\ndisagreement with Mrs. Inglethorp."
"Those witnesses were mistaken."

div.p: I was puzzled. The man spoke with such quiet assurance that I was staggered. I looked at Poirot. There was an expression of exultation on his face which I could not understand. Was he at last convinced of Alfred Inglethorp's guilt?

quote.s: "you have heard your wife's dying\nwords repeated here. Can you explain them in any way?"
"Certainly I can."
"You can?"

"It seems to me very simple. The room was dimly lighted. Dr. Bauerstein\nis much of my height and build, and, like me, wears a beard. In the dim\nlight, and suffering as she was, my poor wife mistook him for me."
"But it is an idea, that!"
"You think it is true?"

div.p: I whispered.

quote.s: "I do not say that. But it is truly an ingenious supposition."
"they were, on the contrary, an appeal to me."

div.p: The Coroner reflected a moment, then he said:

quote.s: "I believe, Mr. Inglethorp, that you yourself poured out the coffee,\nand took it to your wife that evening?"

"I poured it out, yes. But I did not take it to her. I meant to do so,
but I was told that a friend was at the hall door, so I laid down the
coffee on the hall table. When I came through the hall again a few
minutes later, it was gone."

div.p: This statement might, or might not, be true, but it did not seem to me to improve matters much for Inglethorp. In any case, he had had ample time to introduce the poison.
At that point, Poirot nudged me gently, indicating two men who were sitting together near the door. One was a little, sharp, dark, ferret-faced man, the other was tall and fair.
I questioned Poirot mutely. He put his lips to my ear.

quote.s: "Do you know who that little man is?"

div.p: I shook my head.

quote.s: "That is Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard Jimmy Japp.\nThe other man is from Scotland Yard too. Things are moving quickly, my\nfriend."

div.p: I stared at the two men intently. There was certainly nothing of the policeman about them. I should never have suspected them of being official personages.
I was still staring, when I was startled and recalled by the verdict being given:
Wilful Murder against some person or persons unknown.
div.head: CHAPTER VII.
POIROT PAYS HIS DEBTS
div.p: As we came out of the Stylites Arms, Poirot drew me aside by a gentle pressure of the arm. I understood his object. He was waiting for the Scotland Yard men.
In a few moments, they emerged, and Poirot at once stepped forward, and accosted the shorter of the two.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Poirot at once stepped forward and accosted the shorter of the two
quote.s: "I fear you do not remember me, Inspector Japp."

"You've heard me speak of Mr. Poirot? It was in 1904 he and
I worked together the Abercrombie forgery case you remember, he was run
down in Brussels. Ah, those were great days, moosier. Then, do you
remember Baron' Altara? There was a pretty rogue for you! He eluded
the clutches of half the police in Europe. But we nailed him in
Antwerp thanks to Mr. Poirot here."

div.p: As these friendly reminiscences were being indulged in, I drew nearer, and was introduced to Detective-Inspector Japp, who, in his turn, introduced us both to his companion, Superintendent Summerhaye.

quote.s: "I need hardly ask what you are doing here, gentlemen,"

div.p: remarked Poirot.
Japp closed one eye knowingly.

quote.s: "No, indeed. Pretty clear case I should say."

div.p: But Poirot answered gravely:

quote.s: "There I differ from you."
"Surely the whole thing is clear as daylight. The man's caught\nred-handed. How he could be such a fool beats me!"

div.p: But Japp was looking attentively at Poirot.

quote.s:
"Me and Moosier
here have met before and there's no man's judgment I'd sooner take than
his. If I'm not greatly mistaken, he's got something up his sleeve.
Isn't that so, moosier?"

div.p: Poirot smiled.

quote.s: "I have drawn certain conclusions yes."

div.p: Summerhaye was still looking rather sceptical, but Japp continued his scrutiny of Poirot.

quote.s:
"so far, we've only seen the case from the
outside. That's where the Yard's at a disadvantage in a case of this
kind, where the murder's only out, so to speak, after the inquest. A
lot depends on being on the spot first thing, and that's where Mr.
Poirot's had the start of us. We shouldn't have been here as soon as
this even, if it hadn't been for the fact that there was a smart doctor
on the spot, who gave us the tip through the Coroner. But you've been
on the spot from the first, and you may have picked up some little
hints. From the evidence at the inquest, Mr. Inglethorp murdered his
wife as sure as I stand here, and if anyone but you hinted the contrary
I'd laugh in his face. I must say I was surprised the jury didn't bring
it in Wilful Murder against him right off. I think they would have, if
it hadn't been for the Coroner he seemed to be holding them back."
"Perhaps, though, you have a warrant for his arrest in your pocket\nnow,"

div.p: suggested Poirot.
A kind of wooden shutter of officialdom came down from Japp's expressive countenance.

quote.s: "Perhaps I have, and perhaps I haven't,"

div.p: he remarked dryly.
Poirot looked at him thoughtfully.

quote.s: "I am very anxious, Messieurs, that he should not be arrested."
"I dare say,"

div.p: observed Summerhaye sarcastically.
Japp was regarding Poirot with comical perplexity.

quote.s: "Can't you go a little further, Mr. Poirot? A wink's as good as a\nnod from you. You've been on the spot and the Yard doesn't want to make\nany mistakes, you know."

div.p: Poirot nodded gravely.

quote.s: "That is exactly what I thought. Well, I will tell you this. Use your\nwarrant: Arrest Mr. Inglethorp. But it will bring you no kudos the case\nagainst him will be dismissed at once! Comme a!"

div.p: And he snapped his fingers expressively.
Japp's face grew grave, though Summerhaye gave an incredulous snort.
As for me, I was literally dumb with astonishment. I could only conclude that Poirot was mad.
Japp had taken out a handkerchief, and was gently dabbing his brow.

quote.s: "I daren't do it, Mr. Poirot. I'd take your word, but there's others\nover me who'll be asking what the devil I mean by it. Can't you give me\na little more to go on?"

div.p: Poirot reflected a moment.

quote.s:
"I admit I do not wish it. It forces
my hand. I would have preferred to work in the dark just for the
present, but what you say is very just the word of a Belgian policeman,
whose day is past, is not enough! And Alfred Inglethorp must not be
arrested. That I have sworn, as my friend Hastings here knows. See,
then, my good Japp, you go at once to Styles?"
"Well, in about half an hour. We're seeing the Coroner and the doctor\nfirst."

"Good. Call for me in passing the last house in the village. I will go
with you. At Styles, Mr. Inglethorp will give you, or if he refuses as
is probable I will give you such proofs that shall satisfy you that the
case against him could not possibly be sustained. Is that a bargain?"

"And, on behalf of the Yard,
I'm much obliged to you, though I'm bound to confess I can't at present
see the faintest possible loop-hole in the evidence, but you always
were a marvel! So long, then, moosier."

div.p: The two detectives strode away, Summerhaye with an incredulous grin on his face.

quote.s:
"what do
you think? Mon Dieu! I had some warm moments in that court; I did not
figure to myself that the man would be so pig-headed as to refuse to
say anything at all. Decidedly, it was the policy of an imbecile."
"For, if the case against him is true, how could he defend\nhimself except by silence?"
"See; say that it is\nI who have committed this murder, I can think of seven most plausible\nstories! Far more convincing than Mr. Inglethorp's stony denials!"

div.p: I could not help laughing.

quote.s:
"My dear Poirot, I am sure you are capable of thinking of seventy! But,
seriously, in spite of what I heard you say to the detectives, you
surely cannot still believe in the possibility of Alfred Inglethorp's
innocence?"
"Why not now as much as before? Nothing has changed."
"But the evidence is so conclusive."
"Yes, too conclusive."

div.p: We turned in at the gate of Leastways Cottage, and proceeded up the now familiar stairs.

quote.s:
"Real
evidence is usually vague and unsatisfactory. It has to be
examined sifted. But here the whole thing is cut and dried. No, my
friend, this evidence has been very cleverly manufactured so cleverly
that it has defeated its own ends."
"How do you make that out?"

"Because, so long as the evidence against him was vague and intangible,\nit was very hard to disprove. But, in his anxiety, the criminal has\ndrawn the net so closely that one cut will set Inglethorp free."

div.p: I was silent. And in a minute or two, Poirot continued:

quote.s:
"Let us look at the matter like this. Here is a man, let us say, who
sets out to poison his wife. He has lived by his wits as the saying
goes. Presumably, therefore, he has some wits. He is not altogether a
fool. Well, how does he set about it? He goes boldly to the village
chemist's and purchases strychnine under his own name, with a trumped
up story about a dog which is bound to be proved absurd. He does not
employ the poison that night. No, he waits until he has had a violent
quarrel with her, of which the whole household is cognisant, and which
naturally directs their suspicions upon him. He prepares no defence no
shadow of an alibi, yet he knows the chemist's assistant must
necessarily come forward with the facts. Bah! Do not ask me to believe
that any man could be so idiotic! Only a lunatic, who wished to commit
suicide by causing himself to be hanged, would act so!"
"Still I do not see"

div.p: I began.

quote.s: "Neither do I see. I tell you, mon ami, it puzzles me. Me Hercule\nPoirot!"
"But if you believe him innocent, how do you explain his buying the\nstrychnine?"
"Very simply. He did not buy it."
"But Mace recognized him!"

"I beg your pardon, he saw a man with a black beard like Mr.
Inglethorp's, and wearing glasses like Mr. Inglethorp, and dressed in
Mr. Inglethorp's rather noticeable clothes. He could not recognize a
man whom he had probably only seen in the distance, since, you
remember, he himself had only been in the village a fortnight, and Mrs.
Inglethorp dealt principally with Coot's in Tadminster."
"Then you think"
"Mon ami, do you remember the two points I laid stress upon? Leave\nthe first one for the moment, what was the second?"

div.p: The important fact that Alfred Inglethorp wears peculiar clothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses," I quoted.

quote.s: "Exactly. Now suppose anyone wished to pass himself off as John or\nLawrence Cavendish. Would it be easy?"
"Of course an actor"

div.p: But Poirot cut me short ruthlessly.

quote.s:
"And why would it not be easy? I will tell you, my friend: Because they
are both clean-shaven men. To make up successfully as one of these two
in broad daylight, it would need an actor of genius, and a certain
initial facial resemblance. But in the case of Alfred Inglethorp, all
that is changed. His clothes, his beard, the glasses which hide his
eyes those are the salient points about his personal appearance. Now,
what is the first instinct of the criminal? To divert suspicion from
himself, is it not so? And how can he best do that? By throwing it on
someone else. In this instance, there was a man ready to his hand.
Everybody was predisposed to believe in Mr. Inglethorp's guilt. It was
a foregone conclusion that he would be suspected; but, to make it a
sure thing there must be tangible proof such as the actual buying of
the poison, and that, with a man of the peculiar appearance of Mr.
Inglethorp, was not difficult. Remember, this young Mace had never
actually spoken to Mr. Inglethorp. How should he doubt that the man in
his clothes, with his beard and his glasses, was not Alfred
Inglethorp?"
"But, if that\nwas the case, why does he not say where he was at six o'clock on Monday\nevening?"

"If he were arrested, he
probably would speak, but I do not want it to come to that. I must make
him see the gravity of his position. There is, of course, something
discreditable behind his silence. If he did not murder his wife, he is,
nevertheless, a scoundrel, and has something of his own to conceal,
quite apart from the murder."
"What can it be?"

div.p: I mused, won over to Poirot's views for the moment, although still retaining a faint conviction that the obvious deduction was the correct one.

quote.s: "Can you not guess?"

div.p: asked Poirot, smiling.

quote.s: "No, can you?"
"Oh, yes, I had a little idea sometime ago and it has turned out to be\ncorrect."
"You never told me,"

div.p: I said reproachfully.
Poirot spread out his hands apologetically.

quote.s: "Pardon me, mon ami, you were not precisely sympathique."

div.p: He turned to me earnestly.

quote.s: "Tell me you see now that he must not be arrested?"
"Perhaps,"

div.p: I said doubtfully, for I was really quite indifferent to the fate of Alfred Inglethorp, and thought that a good fright would do him no harm.
Poirot, who was watching me intently, gave a sigh.

quote.s: "apart from Mr.\nInglethorp, how did the evidence at the inquest strike you?"
"Oh, pretty much what I expected."
"Did nothing strike you as peculiar about it?"

div.p: My thoughts flew to Mary Cavendish, and I hedged:

quote.s: "In what way?"
"Well, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish's evidence for instance?"

div.p: I was relieved.

quote.s: "Oh, Lawrence! No, I don't think so. He's always a nervous chap."
"His suggestion that his mother might have been poisoned accidentally\nby means of the tonic she was taking, that did not strike you as\nstrange hein?"
"No, I can't say it did. The doctors ridiculed it of course. But it was\nquite a natural suggestion for a layman to make."
"But Monsieur Lawrence is not a layman. You told me yourself that he\nhad started by studying medicine, and that he had taken his degree."
"Yes, that's true. I never thought of that."

div.p: I was rather startled.
