quote.s: "It\nis odd."

div.p: Poirot nodded.

quote.s:
"From the first, his behaviour has been peculiar. Of all the household,
he alone would be likely to recognize the symptoms of strychnine
poisoning, and yet we find him the only member of the family to uphold
strenuously the theory of death from natural causes. If it had been
Monsieur John, I could have understood it. He has no technical
knowledge, and is by nature unimaginative. But Monsieur Lawrence no!
And now, to-day, he puts forward a suggestion that he himself must have
known was ridiculous. There is food for thought in this, mon ami!"
"It's very confusing,"

div.p: I agreed.

quote.s: "That's another who\nis not telling all she knows! What do you make of her attitude?"
"I don't know what to make of it. It seems inconceivable that she\nshould be shielding Alfred Inglethorp. Yet that is what it looks like."

div.p: Poirot nodded reflectively.

quote.s: "Yes, it is queer. One thing is certain, she overheard a good deal more\nof that"

div.p: private conversation'

quote.s: "than she was willing to admit."
"And yet she is the last person one would accuse of stooping to\neavesdrop!"
"Exactly. One thing her evidence has shown me. I made a mistake.\nDorcas was quite right. The quarrel did take place earlier in the\nafternoon, about four o'clock, as she said."

div.p: I looked at him curiously. I had never understood his insistence on that point.

quote.s: "Dr. Bauerstein, now, what was he doing up and dressed at that hour\nin the morning? It is astonishing to me that no one commented on the\nfact."
"He has insomnia, I believe,"

div.p: I said doubtfully.

quote.s: "It\ncovers everything, and explains nothing. I shall keep my eye on our\nclever Dr. Bauerstein."
"Any more faults to find with the evidence?"

div.p: I inquired satirically.

quote.s:
"when you find that people are not
telling you the truth look out! Now, unless I am much mistaken, at the
inquest to-day only one at most, two persons were speaking the truth
without reservation or subterfuge."
"Oh, come now, Poirot! I won't cite Lawrence, or Mrs. Cavendish. But\nthere's John and Miss Howard, surely they were speaking the truth?"
"Both of them, my friend? One, I grant you, but both !"

div.p: His words gave me an unpleasant shock. Miss Howard's evidence, unimportant as it was, had been given in such a downright straightforward manner that it had never occurred to me to doubt her sincerity. Still, I had a great respect for Poirot's sagacity except on the occasions when he was what I described to myself as "foolishly pig-headed.

quote.s: "Miss Howard had always seemed to me\nso essentially honest almost uncomfortably so."

div.p: Poirot gave me a curious look, which I could not quite fathom. He seemed to speak, and then checked himself.

quote.s: "there's nothing untruthful about\nher."
"No. But it was strange that she never heard a sound, sleeping next\ndoor; whereas Mrs. Cavendish, in the other wing of the building,\ndistinctly heard the table fall."
"Well, she's young. And she sleeps soundly."
"Ah, yes, indeed! She must be a famous sleeper, that one!"

div.p: I did not quite like the tone of his voice, but at that moment a smart knock reached our ears, and looking out of the window we perceived the two detectives waiting for us below.

Poirot seized his hat, gave a ferocious twist to his moustache, and, carefully brushing an imaginary speck of dust from his sleeve, motioned me to precede him down the stairs; there we joined the detectives and set out for Styles.

I think the appearance of the two Scotland Yard men was rather a shock especially to John, though of course after the verdict, he had realized that it was only a matter of time. Still, the presence of the detectives brought the truth home to him more than anything else could have done.

Poirot had conferred with Japp in a low tone on the way up, and it was the latter functionary who requested that the household, with the exception of the servants, should be assembled together in the drawing-room. I realized the significance of this. It was up to Poirot to make his boast good.

Personally, I was not sanguine. Poirot might have excellent reasons for his belief in Inglethorp's innocence, but a man of the type of Summerhaye would require tangible proofs, and these I doubted if Poirot could supply.

Before very long we had all trooped into the drawing-room, the door of which Japp closed. Poirot politely set chairs for everyone. The Scotland Yard men were the cynosure of all eyes. I think that for the first time we realized that the thing was not a bad dream, but a tangible reality. We had read of such things now we ourselves were actors in the drama. To-morrow the daily papers, all over England, would blazon out the news in staring headlines:
MYSTERIOUS TRAGEDY IN ESSEX
WEALTHY LADY POISONED

There would be pictures of Styles, snap-shots of "The family leaving the Inquest" the village photographer had not been idle! All the things that one had read a hundred times things that happen to other people, not to oneself. And now, in this house, a murder had been committed. In front of us were "the detectives in charge of the case." The well-known glib phraseology passed rapidly through my mind in the interval before Poirot opened the proceedings.
I think everyone was a little surprised that it should be he and not one of the official detectives who took the initiative.

quote.s: "I have asked you to come here\nall together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred\nInglethorp."

div.p: Inglethorp was sitting a little by himself I think, unconsciously, everyone had drawn his chair slightly away from him and he gave a faint start as Poirot pronounced his name.

quote.s: "a very dark\nshadow is resting on this house the shadow of murder."

div.p: Inglethorp shook his head sadly.

quote.s: "Poor Emily! It is terrible."
"that you quite\nrealize how terrible it may be for you."

div.p: And as Inglethorp did not appear to understand, he added:

quote.s: "Mr. Inglethorp, you are standing in\nvery grave danger."

div.p: The two detectives fidgeted. I saw the official caution "Anything you say will be used in evidence against you," actually hovering on Summerhaye's lips. Poirot went on.

quote.s: "Do you understand now, monsieur?"
"No. What do you mean?"
"that you are suspected of\npoisoning your wife."

div.p: A little gasp ran round the circle at this plain speaking.

quote.s: "What a monstrous idea!\nI poison my dearest Emily!"
"I do not think"

div.p: Poirot watched him narrowly

quote.s:
"that you quite realize
the unfavourable nature of your evidence at the inquest. Mr.
Inglethorp, knowing what I have now told you, do you still refuse to
say where you were at six o'clock on Monday afternoon?"

div.p: With a groan, Alfred Inglethorp sank down again and buried his face in his hands. Poirot approached and stood over him.

quote.s: "Speak!"

div.p: he cried menacingly.
With an effort, Inglethorp raised his face from his hands. Then, slowly and deliberately, he shook his head.
You will not speak?

quote.s: "No. I do not believe that anyone could be so monstrous as to accuse me\nof what you say."

div.p: Poirot nodded thoughtfully, like a man whose mind is made up.

quote.s: "Then I must speak for you."

div.p: Alfred Inglethorp sprang up again.

quote.s: "You? How can you speak? You do not know"

div.p: he broke off abruptly.
Poirot turned to face us.

quote.s:
"Mesdames and messieurs! I speak! Listen!
I, Hercule Poirot, affirm that the man who entered the chemist's shop,
and purchased strychnine at six o'clock on Monday last was not Mr.
Inglethorp, for at six o'clock on that day Mr. Inglethorp was escorting
Mrs. Raikes back to her home from a neighbouring farm. I can produce no
less than five witnesses to swear to having seen them together, either
at six or just after and, as you may know, the Abbey Farm, Mrs.
Raikes's home, is at least two and a half miles distant from the
village. There is absolutely no question as to the alibi!"

div.head: CHAPTER VIII.
FRESH SUSPICIONS
div.p: There was a moment's stupefied silence. Japp, who was the least surprised of any of us, was the first to speak.

quote.s: "you're the goods! And no mistake, Mr. Poirot!\nThese witnesses of yours are all right, I suppose?"
"Voil ! I have prepared a list of them names and addresses. You must\nsee them, of course. But you will find it all right."
"I'm sure of that."

div.p: Japp lowered his voice.

quote.s: "I'm much obliged to you. A\npretty mare's nest arresting him would have been."

div.p: He turned to Inglethorp.

quote.s: "But, if you'll excuse me, sir, why couldn't you say all\nthis at the inquest?"
"There was a certain\nrumour"
"A most malicious and utterly untrue one,"

div.p: interrupted Alfred Inglethorp in an agitated voice.

quote.s: "And Mr. Inglethorp was anxious to have no scandal revived just at\npresent. Am I right?"
"Quite right."

div.p: Inglethorp nodded.

quote.s: "With my poor Emily not yet buried,\ncan you wonder I was anxious that no more lying rumours should be\nstarted."

"I'd sooner have any amount
of rumours than be arrested for murder. And I venture to think your
poor lady would have felt the same. And, if it hadn't been for Mr.
Poirot here, arrested you would have been, as sure as eggs is eggs!"
"But you do not know,\ninspector, how I have been persecuted and maligned."

div.p: And he shot a baleful glance at Evelyn Howard.

quote.s:
"I should like to see
the lady's bedroom, please, and after that I'll have a little chat with
the servants. Don't you bother about anything. Mr. Poirot, here, will
show me the way."

div.p: As they all went out of the room, Poirot turned and made me a sign to follow him upstairs. There he caught me by the arm, and drew me aside.

quote.s: "Quick, go to the other wing. Stand there just this side of the baize\ndoor. Do not move till I come."

div.p: Then, turning rapidly, he rejoined the two detectives.

I followed his instructions, taking up my position by the baize door, and wondering what on earth lay behind the request. Why was I to stand in this particular spot on guard? I looked thoughtfully down the corridor in front of me. An idea struck me. With the exception of Cynthia Murdoch's, everyone's room was in this left wing. Had that anything to do with it? Was I to report who came or went? I stood faithfully at my post. The minutes passed. Nobody came. Nothing happened.
It must have been quite twenty minutes before Poirot rejoined me.

quote.s: "You have not stirred?"
"No, I've stuck here like a rock. Nothing's happened."
"Ah!"

div.p: Was he pleased, or disappointed?

quote.s: "You've seen nothing at all?"
"No."
"But you have probably heard something? A big bump eh, mon ami?"
"No."
"Is it possible? Ah, but I am vexed with myself! I am not usually\nclumsy. I made but a slight gesture"

div.p: I know Poirot's gestures

quote.s: "with the\nleft hand, and over went the table by the bed!"

div.p: He looked so childishly vexed and crest-fallen that I hastened to console him.

quote.s:
"Never mind, old chap. What does it matter? Your triumph downstairs
excited you. I can tell you, that was a surprise to us all. There must
be more in this affair of Inglethorp's with Mrs. Raikes than we
thought, to make him hold his tongue so persistently. What are you
going to do now? Where are the Scotland Yard fellows?"
"Gone down to interview the servants. I showed them all our exhibits. I\nam disappointed in Japp. He has no method!"
"Here's Dr. Bauerstein. I\nbelieve you're right about that man, Poirot. I don't like him."
"He is clever,"

div.p: observed Poirot meditatively.

quote.s: "Oh, clever as the devil! I must say I was overjoyed to see him in the\nplight he was in on Tuesday. You never saw such a spectacle!"

div.p: And I described the doctor's adventure.

quote.s: "He looked a regular scarecrow!\nPlastered with mud from head to foot."
"You saw him, then?"
"Yes. Of course, he didn't want to come in it was just after dinner but\nMr. Inglethorp insisted."
"What?"

div.p: Poirot caught me violently by the shoulders.

quote.s: "Was Dr.\nBauerstein here on Tuesday evening? Here? And you never told me? Why\ndid you not tell me? Why? Why?"

div.p: He appeared to be in an absolute frenzy.

quote.s: "I never thought it would interest\nyou. I didn't know it was of any importance."
"Importance? It is of the first importance! So Dr. Bauerstein was here\non Tuesday night the night of the murder. Hastings, do you not see?\nThat alters everything everything!"

div.p: I had never seen him so upset. Loosening his hold of me, he mechanically straightened a pair of candlesticks, still murmuring to himself:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he mechanically straightened a pair of candlesticks still murmuring to himself
quote.s: "Yes, that alters everything everything."

div.p: Suddenly he seemed to come to a decision.

quote.s: "We must act at once. Where is Mr. Cavendish?"

div.p: John was in the smoking-room. Poirot went straight to him.

quote.s: "Mr. Cavendish, I have some important business in Tadminster. A new\nclue. May I take your motor?"
"Why, of course. Do you mean at once?"
"If you please."

div.p: John rang the bell, and ordered round the car. In another ten minutes, we were racing down the park and along the high road to Tadminster.

quote.s: "perhaps you will tell me what\nall this is about?"

"Well, mon ami, a good deal you can guess for yourself. Of course you
realize that, now Mr. Inglethorp is out of it, the whole position is
greatly changed. We are face to face with an entirely new problem. We
know now that there is one person who did not buy the poison. We have
cleared away the manufactured clues. Now for the real ones. I have
ascertained that anyone in the household, with the exception of Mrs.
Cavendish, who was playing tennis with you, could have personated Mr.
Inglethorp on Monday evening. In the same way, we have his statement
that he put the coffee down in the hall. No one took much notice of
that at the inquest but now it has a very different significance. We
must find out who did take that coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp eventually,
or who passed through the hall whilst it was standing there. From your
account, there are only two people whom we can positively say did not
go near the coffee Mrs. Cavendish, and Mademoiselle Cynthia."
"Yes, that is so."

div.p: I felt an inexpressible lightening of the heart. Mary Cavendish could certainly not rest under suspicion.

quote.s: "Tell\nme, Hastings, you yourself have you no suspicions of anybody?"

div.p: I hesitated. To tell the truth, an idea, wild and extravagant in itself, had once or twice that morning flashed through my brain. I had rejected it as absurd, nevertheless it persisted.

quote.s: "It's so utterly\nfoolish."
"Do not fear. Speak your mind.\nYou should always pay attention to your instincts."
"it's absurd but I suspect Miss Howard of\nnot telling all she knows!"
"Miss Howard?"
"Yes you'll laugh at me"
"Not at all. Why should I?"

"that we've rather
left her out of the possible suspects, simply on the strength of her
having been away from the place. But, after all, she was only fifteen
miles away. A car would do it in half an hour. Can we say positively
that she was away from Styles on the night of the murder?"
"we can. One of my first\nactions was to ring up the hospital where she was working."
"Well?"

"Well, I learnt that Miss Howard had been on afternoon duty on Tuesday,
and that a convoy coming in unexpectedly she had kindly offered to
remain on night duty, which offer was gratefully accepted. That
disposes of that."
"Oh!"

div.p: I said, rather nonplussed.

quote.s:
"it's her
extraordinary vehemence against Inglethorp that started me off
suspecting her. I can't help feeling she'd do anything against him. And
I had an idea she might know something about the destroying of the
will. She might have burnt the new one, mistaking it for the earlier
one in his favour. She is so terribly bitter against him."
"You consider her vehemence unnatural?"
"Y es. She is so very violent. I wondered really whether she is quite\nsane on that point."

div.p: Poirot shook his head energetically.

quote.s: "No, no, you are on a wrong tack there. There is nothing weak-minded or\ndegenerate about Miss Howard. She is an excellent specimen of\nwell-balanced English beef and brawn. She is sanity itself."

"Yet her hatred of Inglethorp seems almost a mania. My idea was a very
ridiculous one, no doubt that she had intended to poison him and that,
in some way, Mrs. Inglethorp got hold of it by mistake. But I don't at
all see how it could have been done. The whole thing is absurd and
ridiculous to the last degree."

"Still you are right in one thing. It is always wise to suspect
everybody until you can prove logically, and to your own satisfaction,
that they are innocent. Now, what reasons are there against Miss
Howard's having deliberately poisoned Mrs. Inglethorp?"
"Why, she was devoted to her!"

div.p: I exclaimed.

quote.s:
"You argue like a child. If Miss
Howard were capable of poisoning the old lady, she would be quite
equally capable of simulating devotion. No, we must look elsewhere. You
are perfectly correct in your assumption that her vehemence against
Alfred Inglethorp is too violent to be natural; but you are quite wrong
in the deduction you draw from it. I have drawn my own deductions,
which I believe to be correct, but I will not speak of them at
present."

div.p: He paused a minute, then went on.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: He paused a minute then went on
quote.s: "Now, to my way of\nthinking, there is one insuperable objection to Miss Howard's being the\nmurderess."
"And that is?"
"That in no possible way could Mrs. Inglethorp's death benefit Miss\nHoward. Now there is no murder without a motive."

div.p: I reflected.

quote.s: "Could not Mrs. Inglethorp have made a will in her favour?"

div.p: Poirot shook his head.

quote.s: "But you yourself suggested that possibility to Mr. Wells?"

div.p: Poirot smiled.

quote.s: "That was for a reason. I did not want to mention the name of the\nperson who was actually in my mind. Miss Howard occupied very much the\nsame position, so I used her name instead."
"Still, Mrs. Inglethorp might have done so. Why, that will, made on the\nafternoon of her death may"

div.p: But Poirot's shake of the head was so energetic that I stopped.

quote.s: "No, my friend. I have certain little ideas of my own about that will.\nBut I can tell you this much it was not in Miss Howard's favour."

div.p: I accepted his assurance, though I did not really see how he could be so positive about the matter.

quote.s: "we will acquit Miss Howard, then. It is\npartly your fault that I ever came to suspect her. It was what you said\nabout her evidence at the inquest that set me off."

div.p: Poirot looked puzzled.

quote.s: "What did I say about her evidence at the inquest?"
"Don't you remember? When I cited her and John Cavendish as being above\nsuspicion?"
"Oh ah yes."

div.p: He seemed a little confused, but recovered himself.

quote.s: "By\nthe way, Hastings, there is something I want you to do for me."
"Certainly. What is it?"
"Next time you happen to be alone with Lawrence Cavendish, I want you\nto say this to him. I have a message for you, from Poirot. He says:"

div.p: Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace!

quote.s: "' Nothing more.\nNothing less."

div.p: Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.'

quote.s: "Is that\nright?"

div.p: I asked, much mystified.

quote.s: "Excellent."
"But what does it mean?"
"Ah, that I will leave you to find out. You have access to the facts.\nJust say that to him, and see what he says."
"Very well but it's all extremely mysterious."

div.p: We were running into Tadminster now, and Poirot directed the car to the Analytical Chemist.
Poirot hopped down briskly, and went inside. In a few minutes he was back again.

quote.s: "That is all my business."
"What were you doing there?"

div.p: I asked, in lively curiosity.

quote.s: "I left something to be analysed."
"Yes, but what?"
"The sample of cocoa I took from the saucepan in the bedroom."
"Dr. Bauerstein\nhad it tested, and you yourself laughed at the possibility of there\nbeing strychnine in it."
"I know Dr. Bauerstein had it tested,"

div.p: replied Poirot quietly.

quote.s: "Well, then?"
"Well, I have a fancy for having it analysed again, that is all."

div.p: And not another word on the subject could I drag out of him.

This proceeding of Poirot's, in respect of the cocoa, puzzled me intensely. I could see neither rhyme nor reason in it. However, my confidence in him, which at one time had rather waned, was fully restored since his belief in Alfred Inglethorp's innocence had been so triumphantly vindicated.

The funeral of Mrs. Inglethorp took place the following day, and on Monday, as I came down to a late breakfast, John drew me aside, and informed me that Mr. Inglethorp was leaving that morning, to take up his quarters at the Stylites Arms until he should have completed his plans.

quote.s:
"It was bad enough before, when we thought
he'd done it, but I'm hanged if it isn't worse now, when we all feel
guilty for having been so down on the fellow. The fact is, we've
treated him abominably. Of course, things did look black against him. I
don't see how anyone could blame us for jumping to the conclusions we
did. Still, there it is, we were in the wrong, and now there's a
beastly feeling that one ought to make amends; which is difficult, when
one doesn't like the fellow a bit better than one did before. The whole
thing's damned awkward! And I'm thankful he's had the tact to take
himself off. It's a good thing Styles wasn't the mater's to leave to
him. Couldn't bear to think of the fellow lording it here. He's welcome
to her money."
"You'll be able to keep up the place all right?"

div.p: I asked.

quote.s:
"Oh, yes. There are the death duties, of course, but half my father's
money goes with the place, and Lawrence will stay with us for the
present, so there is his share as well. We shall be pinched at first,
of course, because, as I once told you, I am in a bit of a hole
financially myself. Still, the Johnnies will wait now."

div.p: In the general relief at Inglethorp's approaching departure, we had the most genial breakfast we had experienced since the tragedy. Cynthia, whose young spirits were naturally buoyant, was looking quite her pretty self again, and we all, with the exception of Lawrence, who seemed unalterably gloomy and nervous, were quietly cheerful, at the opening of a new and hopeful future.

The papers, of course, had been full of the tragedy. Glaring headlines, sandwiched biographies of every member of the household, subtle innuendoes, the usual familiar tag about the police having a clue. Nothing was spared us. It was a slack time. The war was momentarily inactive, and the newspapers seized with avidity on this crime in fashionable life: "The Mysterious Affair at Styles" was the topic of the moment.

Naturally it was very annoying for the Cavendishes. The house was constantly besieged by reporters, who were consistently denied admission, but who continued to haunt the village and the grounds, where they lay in wait with cameras, for any unwary members of the household. We all lived in a blast of publicity. The Scotland Yard men came and went, examining, questioning, lynx-eyed and reserved of tongue. Towards what end they were working, we did not know. Had they any clue, or would the whole thing remain in the category of undiscovered crimes?
After breakfast, Dorcas came up to me rather mysteriously, and asked if she might have a few words with me.

quote.s: "Certainly. What is it, Dorcas?"
"Well, it's just this, sir. You'll be seeing the Belgian gentleman\nto-day perhaps?"

div.p: I nodded.

quote.s: "Well, sir, you know how he asked me so\nparticular if the mistress, or anyone else, had a green dress?"
"Yes, yes. You have found one?"

div.p: My interest was aroused.

quote.s: "No, not that, sir. But since then I've remembered what the young\ngentlemen"

div.p: John and Lawrence were still the "young gentlemen" to Dorcas

quote.s:
"call the dressing-up box.' It's up in the front attic, sir. A
great chest, full of old clothes and fancy dresses, and what not. And
it came to me sudden like that there might be a green dress amongst
them. So, if you'd tell the Belgian gentleman"
"I will tell him, Dorcas,"

div.p: I promised.

quote.s:
"Thank you very much, sir. A very nice gentleman he is, sir. And quite
a different class from them two detectives from London, what goes
prying about, and asking questions. I don't hold with foreigners as a
rule, but from what the newspapers say I make out as how these brave
Belges isn't the ordinary run of foreigners, and certainly he's a most
polite spoken gentleman."

div.p: Dear old Dorcas! As she stood there, with her honest face upturned to mine, I thought what a fine specimen she was of the old-fashioned servant that is so fast dying out.
I thought I might as well go down to the village at once, and look up Poirot; but I met him half-way, coming up to the house, and at once gave him Dorcas's message.

quote.s: "Ah, the brave Dorcas! We will look at the chest, although but no\nmatter we will examine it all the same."

div.p: We entered the house by one of the windows. There was no one in the hall, and we went straight up to the attic.
Sure enough, there was the chest, a fine old piece, all studded with brass nails, and full to overflowing with every imaginable type of garment.

Poirot bundled everything out on the floor with scant ceremony. There were one or two green fabrics of varying shades; but Poirot shook his head over them all. He seemed somewhat apathetic in the search, as though he expected no great results from it. Suddenly he gave an exclamation.

quote.s: "What is it?"
"Look!"

div.p: The chest was nearly empty, and there, reposing right at the bottom, was a magnificent black beard.

quote.s: "Oh !"

div.p: He turned it over in his hands, examining it closely.

quote.s: "Yes, quite new."

div.p: After a moment's hesitation, he replaced it in the chest, heaped all the other things on top of it as before, and made his way briskly downstairs. He went straight to the pantry, where we found Dorcas busily polishing her silver.
Poirot wished her good morning with Gallic politeness, and went on:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Poirot wished her good morning with Gallic politeness and went on
quote.s: "We have been looking through that chest, Dorcas. I am much obliged to\nyou for mentioning it. There is, indeed, a fine collection there. Are\nthey often used, may I ask?"
"Well, sir, not very often nowadays, though from time to time we do\nhave what the young gentlemen call"

div.p: a dress-up night.'

quote.s:
"And very funny
it is sometimes, sir. Mr. Lawrence, he's wonderful. Most comic! I shall
never forget the night he came down as the Char of Persia, I think he
called it a sort of Eastern King it was. He had the big paper knife in
his hand, and"

div.p: Mind, Dorcas,'

quote.s: "he says,"

div.p: you'll have to be very respectful. This is my specially sharpened scimitar, and it's off with your head if I'm at all displeased with you!'

quote.s:
"Miss Cynthia, she was
what they call an Apache, or some such name a Frenchified sort of
cut-throat, I take it to be. A real sight she looked. You'd never have
believed a pretty young lady like that could have made herself into
such a ruffian. Nobody would have known her."
"I\nsuppose Mr. Lawrence wore that fine black beard in the chest upstairs,\nwhen he was Shah of Persia?"

"And well I know
it, for he borrowed two skeins of my black wool to make it with! And
I'm sure it looked wonderfully natural at a distance. I didn't know as
there was a beard up there at all. It must have been got quite lately,
I think. There was a red wig, I know, but nothing else in the way of
hair. Burnt corks they use mostly though tis messy getting it off
again. Miss Cynthia was a nigger once, and, oh, the trouble she had."
"So Dorcas knows nothing about that black beard,"

div.p: said Poirot thoughtfully, as we walked out into the hall again.

quote.s: "Do you think it is the one?"

div.p: I whispered eagerly.
Poirot nodded.

quote.s: "I do. You notice it had been trimmed?"
"No."
"Yes. It was cut exactly the shape of Mr. Inglethorp's, and I found one\nor two snipped hairs. Hastings, this affair is very deep."
"Who put it in the chest, I wonder?"

"You
realize that he chose the one place in the house to hide it where its
presence would not be remarked? Yes, he is intelligent. But we must be
more intelligent. We must be so intelligent that he does not suspect us
of being intelligent at all."

div.p: I acquiesced.

quote.s: "There, mon ami, you will be of great assistance to me."

div.p: I was pleased with the compliment. There had been times when I hardly thought that Poirot appreciated me at my true worth.

quote.s: "you will be\ninvaluable."

div.p: This was naturally gratifying, but Poirot's next words were not so welcome.

quote.s: "I must have an ally in the house,"

div.p: he observed reflectively.

quote.s: "You have me,"

div.p: I protested.

quote.s: "true, but you are not sufficient."

div.p: I was hurt, and showed it. Poirot hurried to explain himself.

quote.s: "You do not quite take my meaning. You are known to be working with me.\nI want somebody who is not associated with us in any way."
"Oh, I see. How about John?"
"No, I think not."
"The dear fellow isn't perhaps very bright,"

div.p: I said thoughtfully.

quote.s: "She is the very\nperson. But I am in her black books, since I cleared Mr. Inglethorp.\nStill, we can but try."

div.p: With a nod that was barely civil, Miss Howard assented to Poirot's request for a few minutes' conversation.
We went into the little morning-room, and Poirot closed the door.

quote.s: "what is it? Out\nwith it. I'm busy."
"Do you remember, mademoiselle, that I once asked you to help me?"
"Yes, I do."

div.p: The lady nodded.

quote.s: "And I told you I'd help you with\npleasure to hang Alfred Inglethorp."
"Ah!"

div.p: Poirot studied her seriously.

quote.s: "Miss Howard, I will ask you one\nquestion. I beg of you to reply to it truthfully."
"Never tell lies,"

div.p: replied Miss Howard.

quote.s: "It is this. Do you still believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by\nher husband?"

"You needn't think your pretty
explanations influence me in the slightest. I'll admit that it wasn't
he who bought strychnine at the chemist's shop. What of that? I dare
say he soaked fly paper, as I told you at the beginning."
"That is arsenic not strychnine,"

div.p: said Poirot mildly.

quote.s: "What does that matter? Arsenic would put poor Emily out of the way\njust as well as strychnine. If I'm convinced he did it, it doesn't\nmatter a jot to me how he did it."
"I\nwill put my question in another form. Did you ever in your heart of\nhearts believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband?"
"Haven't I always told you the man\nis a villain? Haven't I always told you he would murder her in her bed?\nHaven't I always hated him like poison?"
"That bears out my little idea entirely."
"What little idea?"

"Miss Howard, do you remember a conversation that took place on the day
of my friend's arrival here? He repeated it to me, and there is a
sentence of yours that has impressed me very much. Do you remember
affirming that if a crime had been committed, and anyone you loved had
been murdered, you felt certain that you would know by instinct who the
criminal was, even if you were quite unable to prove it?"
"Yes, I remember saying that. I believe it too. I suppose you think it\nnonsense?"
"Not at all."
"And yet you will pay no attention to my instinct against Alfred\nInglethorp."
"Because your instinct is not against Mr.\nInglethorp."
"What?"
"No. You wish to believe he committed the crime. You believe him\ncapable of committing it. But your instinct tells you he did not commit\nit. It tells you more shall I go on?"

div.p: She was staring at him, fascinated, and made a slight affirmative movement of the hand.

quote.s:
"Shall I tell you why you have been so vehement against Mr. Inglethorp?
It is because you have been trying to believe what you wish to believe.
It is because you are trying to drown and stifle your instinct, which
tells you another name"
"Don't\nsay it! Oh, don't say it! It isn't true! It can't be true. I don't know\nwhat put such a wild such a dreadful idea into my head!"
"I am right, am I not?"

div.p: asked Poirot.

quote.s: "Yes, yes; you must be a wizard to have guessed. But it can't be\nso it's too monstrous, too impossible. It must be Alfred Inglethorp."

div.p: Poirot shook his head gravely.

quote.s: "because I shan't tell\nyou. I won't admit it, even to myself. I must be mad to think of such a\nthing."

div.p: Poirot nodded, as if satisfied.

quote.s: "I will ask you nothing. It is enough for me that it is as I thought.\nAnd I I, too, have an instinct. We are working together towards a\ncommon end."
"Don't ask me to help you, because I won't. I wouldn't lift a finger\nto to"

div.p: She faltered.

quote.s: "You will help me in spite of yourself. I ask you nothing but you will\nbe my ally. You will not be able to help yourself. You will do the only\nthing that I want of you."
"And that is?"
"You will watch!"

div.p: Evelyn Howard bowed her head.

quote.s: "Yes, I can't help doing that. I am always watching always hoping I\nshall be proved wrong."
"No one will be more\npleased than I shall. But, if we are right? If we are right, Miss\nHoward, on whose side are you then?"
"I don't know, I don't know"
"Come now."
"It could be hushed up."
"There must be no hushing up."
"But Emily herself"

div.p: She broke off.

quote.s: "this is unworthy of you."

div.p: Suddenly she took her face from her hands.

quote.s: "This is Evelyn Howard! And she is on the\nside of Justice! Let the cost be what it may."

div.p: And with these words, she walked firmly out of the room.

quote.s: "goes a very valuable ally.\nThat woman, Hastings, has got brains as well as a heart."

div.p: I did not reply.

quote.s: "It can neither be\nexplained nor ignored."
"Perhaps you don't realize that I am still in the\ndark."
"Really? Is that so, mon ami?"
"Yes. Enlighten me, will you?"

div.p: Poirot studied me attentively for a moment or two. Then, to my intense surprise, he shook his head decidedly.

quote.s: "No, my friend."
"Oh, look here, why not?"
"Two is enough for a secret."
"Well, I think it is very unfair to keep back facts from me."
"I am not keeping back facts. Every fact that I know is in your\npossession. You can draw your own deductions from them. This time it is\na question of ideas."
"Still, it would be interesting to know."

div.p: Poirot looked at me very earnestly, and again shook his head.

quote.s: "you have no instincts."
"It was intelligence you were requiring just now,"

div.p: I pointed out.

quote.s: "The two often go together,"

div.p: said Poirot enigmatically.

The remark seemed so utterly irrelevant that I did not even take the trouble to answer it. But I decided that if I made any interesting and important discoveries as no doubt I should I would keep them to myself, and surprise Poirot with the ultimate result.
There are times when it is one's duty to assert oneself.
div.head: CHAPTER IX.
div.p: DR. BAUERSTEIN

I had had no opportunity as yet of passing on Poirot's message to Lawrence. But now, as I strolled out on the lawn, still nursing a grudge against my friend's high-handedness, I saw Lawrence on the croquet lawn, aimlessly knocking a couple of very ancient balls about, with a still more ancient mallet.

It struck me that it would be a good opportunity to deliver my message. Otherwise, Poirot himself might relieve me of it. It was true that I did not quite gather its purport, but I flattered myself that by Lawrence's reply, and perhaps a little skillful cross-examination on my part, I should soon perceive its significance. Accordingly I accosted him.

quote.s: "I've been looking for you,"

div.p: I remarked untruthfully.

quote.s: "Have you?"
"Yes. The truth is, I've got a message for you from Poirot."
"Yes?"
"He told me to wait until I was alone with you,"

div.p: I said, dropping my voice significantly, and watching him intently out of the corner of my eye. I have always been rather good at what is called, I believe, creating an atmosphere.

quote.s: "Well?"

div.p: There was no change of expression in the dark melancholic face. Had he any idea of what I was about to say?

quote.s: "This is the message."

div.p: I dropped my voice still lower. " Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.'

quote.s: "What on earth does he mean?"

div.p: Lawrence stared at me in quite unaffected astonishment.

quote.s: "Don't you know?"
"Not in the least. Do you?"

div.p: I was compelled to shake my head.

quote.s: "What extra coffee-cup?"
"I don't know."

"He'd better ask Dorcas, or one of the maids, if he wants to know about
coffee-cups. It's their business, not mine. I don't know anything about
the coffee-cups, except that we've got some that are never used, which
are a perfect dream! Old Worcester. You're not a connoisseur, are you,
Hastings?"

div.p: I shook my head.

quote.s: "You miss a lot. A really perfect bit of old china it's pure delight to\nhandle it, or even to look at it."
"Well, what am I to tell Poirot?"
"Tell him I don't know what he's talking about. It's double Dutch to\nme."
"All right."

div.p: I was moving off towards the house again when he suddenly called me back.

quote.s: "I say, what was the end of that message? Say it over again, will you?"

div.p: Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.'

quote.s: "Are you sure\nyou don't know what it means?"

div.p: I asked him earnestly.
He shook his head.

quote.s: "I don't. I I wish I did."

div.p: The boom of the gong sounded from the house, and we went in together. Poirot had been asked by John to remain to lunch, and was already seated at the table.

By tacit consent, all mention of the tragedy was barred. We conversed on the war, and other outside topics. But after the cheese and biscuits had been handed round, and Dorcas had left the room, Poirot suddenly leant forward to Mrs. Cavendish.

quote.s: "Pardon me, madame, for recalling unpleasant memories, but I have a\nlittle idea"

div.p: Poirot's "little ideas" were becoming a perfect byword

quote.s: "and would like to ask one or two questions."
"Of me? Certainly."
"You are too amiable, madame. What I want to ask is this: the door\nleading into Mrs. Inglethorp's room from that of Mademoiselle Cynthia,\nit was bolted, you say?"
"I\nsaid so at the inquest."
"Bolted?"
"Yes."

div.p: She looked perplexed.

quote.s: "you are sure it was bolted, and not merely\nlocked?"
"Oh, I see what you mean. No, I don't know. I said bolted, meaning that\nit was fastened, and I could not open it, but I believe all the doors\nwere found bolted on the inside."
"Still, as far as you are concerned, the door might equally well have\nbeen locked?"
"Oh, yes."
"You yourself did not happen to notice, madame, when you entered Mrs.\nInglethorp's room, whether that door was bolted or not?"
"I I believe it was."
"But you did not see it?"
"No. I never looked."
"I happened to notice\nthat it was bolted."
"Ah, that settles it."

div.p: And Poirot looked crestfallen.
I could not help rejoicing that, for once, one of his "little ideas had come to naught.
After lunch Poirot begged me to accompany him home. I consented rather stiffly.

quote.s: "You are annoyed, is it not so?"

div.p: he asked anxiously, as we walked through the park.

quote.s: "Not at all,"

div.p: I said coldly.

quote.s: "That is well. That lifts a great load from my mind."

div.p: This was not quite what I had intended. I had hoped that he would have observed the stiffness of my manner. Still, the fervour of his words went towards the appeasing of my just displeasure. I thawed.

quote.s: "I gave Lawrence your message,"

div.p: I said.

quote.s: "And what did he say? He was entirely puzzled?"
"Yes. I am quite sure he had no idea of what you meant."

div.p: I had expected Poirot to be disappointed; but, to my surprise, he replied that that was as he had thought, and that he was very glad. My pride forbade me to ask any questions.
Poirot switched off on another tack.

quote.s: "Mademoiselle Cynthia was not at lunch to-day? How was that?"
"She is at the hospital again. She resumed work to-day."
"Ah, she is an industrious little demoiselle. And pretty too. She is\nlike pictures I have seen in Italy. I would rather like to see that\ndispensary of hers. Do you think she would show it to me?"
"I am sure she would be delighted. It's an interesting little place."
"Does she go there every day?"
"She has all Wednesdays off, and comes back to lunch on Saturdays.\nThose are her only times off."
"I will remember. Women are doing great work nowadays, and Mademoiselle\nCynthia is clever oh, yes, she has brains, that little one."
"Yes. I believe she has passed quite a stiff exam."
"Without doubt. After all, it is very responsible work. I suppose they\nhave very strong poisons there?"
"Yes, she showed them to us. They are kept locked up in a little\ncupboard. I believe they have to be very careful. They always take out\nthe key before leaving the room."
"Indeed. It is near the window, this cupboard?"
"No, right the other side of the room. Why?"

div.p: Poirot shrugged his shoulders.

quote.s: "I wondered. That is all. Will you come in?"

div.p: We had reached the cottage.

quote.s: "No. I think I'll be getting back. I shall go round the long way\nthrough the woods."

div.p: The woods round Styles were very beautiful. After the walk across the open park, it was pleasant to saunter lazily through the cool glades. There was hardly a breath of wind, the very chirp of the birds was faint and subdued. I strolled on a little way, and finally flung myself down at the foot of a grand old beech-tree. My thoughts of mankind were kindly and charitable. I even forgave Poirot for his absurd secrecy. In fact, I was at peace with the world. Then I yawned.
I thought about the crime, and it struck me as being very unreal and far off.
I yawned again.

Probably, I thought, it really never happened. Of course, it was all a bad dream. The truth of the matter was that it was Lawrence who had murdered Alfred Inglethorp with a croquet mallet. But it was absurd of John to make such a fuss about it, and to go shouting out:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: John to make such a fuss about it and to go shouting out
quote.s: "I tell you\nI won't have it!"

div.p: I woke up with a start.

At once I realized that I was in a very awkward predicament. For, about twelve feet away from me, John and Mary Cavendish were standing facing each other, and they were evidently quarrelling. And, quite as evidently, they were unaware of my vicinity, for before I could move or speak John repeated the words which had aroused me from my dream.

quote.s: "I tell you, Mary, I won't have it."

div.p: Mary's voice came, cool and liquid:

quote.s: "Have you any right to criticize my actions?"
"It will be the talk of the village! My mother was only buried on\nSaturday, and here you are gadding about with the fellow."
"Oh,"

div.p: she shrugged her shoulders,

quote.s: "if it is only village gossip that\nyou mind!"
"But it isn't. I've had enough of the fellow hanging about. He's a\nPolish Jew, anyway."
"A tinge of Jewish blood is not a bad thing. It leavens the"

div.p: she looked at him

quote.s: "stolid stupidity of the ordinary Englishman."

div.p: Fire in her eyes, ice in her voice. I did not wonder that the blood rose to John's face in a crimson tide.

quote.s: "Mary!"
"Well?"

div.p: Her tone did not change.
The pleading died out of his voice.

quote.s: "Am I to understand that you will continue to see Bauerstein against my\nexpress wishes?"
"If I choose."
"You defy me?"
"No, but I deny your right to criticize my actions. Have you no\nfriends of whom I should disapprove?"

div.p: John fell back a pace. The colour ebbed slowly from his face.

quote.s: "What do you mean?"

div.p: he said, in an unsteady voice.

quote.s: "You do see, don't you, that you have\nno right to dictate to me as to the choice of my friends?"

div.p: John glanced at her pleadingly, a stricken look on his face.

quote.s: "Mary"

div.p: For a moment, I thought she wavered. A softer expression came over her face, then suddenly she turned almost fiercely away.

quote.s: "null!"

div.p: She was walking away when John sprang after her, and caught her by the arm.

quote.s: "Mary"

div.p: his voice was very quiet now

quote.s: "are you in love with this fellow\nBauerstein?"

div.p: She hesitated, and suddenly there swept across her face a strange expression, old as the hills, yet with something eternally young about it. So might some Egyptian sphinx have smiled.
She freed herself quietly from his arm, and spoke over her shoulder.

quote.s: "Perhaps,"

div.p: she said; and then swiftly passed out of the little glade, leaving John standing there as though he had been turned to stone.
Rather ostentatiously, I stepped forward, crackling some dead branches with my feet as I did so. John turned. Luckily, he took it for granted that I had only just come upon the scene.

quote.s: "Hullo, Hastings. Have you seen the little fellow safely back to his\ncottage? Quaint little chap! Is he any good, though, really?"
"He was considered one of the finest detectives of his day."
"Oh, well, I suppose there must be something in it, then. What a rotten\nworld it is, though!"
"You find it so?"

div.p: I asked.

quote.s:
"Good Lord, yes! There's this terrible business to start with. Scotland
Yard men in and out of the house like a jack-in-the-box! Never know
where they won't turn up next. Screaming headlines in every paper in
the country damn all journalists, I say! Do you know there was a whole
crowd staring in at the lodge gates this morning. Sort of Madame
Tussaud's chamber of horrors business that can be seen for nothing.
Pretty thick, isn't it?"
"It can't last for ever."
"Can't it, though? It can last long enough for us never to be able to\nhold up our heads again."
"No, no, you're getting morbid on the subject."
"Enough to make a man morbid, to be stalked by beastly journalists and\nstared at by gaping moon-faced idiots, wherever he goes! But there's\nworse than that."
"What?"

div.p: John lowered his voice:

quote.s:
"Have you ever thought, Hastings it's a nightmare to me who did it? I
can't help feeling sometimes it must have been an accident.
Because because who could have done it? Now Inglethorp's out of the
way, there's no one else; no one, I mean, except one of us."

div.p: Yes, indeed, that was nightmare enough for any man! One of us? Yes, surely it must be so, unless -

A new idea suggested itself to my mind. Rapidly, I considered it. The light increased. Poirot's mysterious doings, his hints they all fitted in. Fool that I was not to have thought of this possibility before, and what a relief for us all.

quote.s: "it isn't one of us. How could it be?"
"I know, but, still, who else is there?"
"Can't you guess?"
"No."

div.p: I looked cautiously round, and lowered my voice.

quote.s: "Dr. Bauerstein!"

div.p: I whispered.

quote.s: "Impossible!"
"Not at all."
"But what earthly interest could he have in my mother's death?"
"but I'll tell you this: Poirot thinks\nso."
"Poirot? Does he? How do you know?"

div.p: I told him of Poirot's intense excitement on hearing that Dr. Bauerstein had been at Styles on the fatal night, and added:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: I told him of Poirots intense excitement on hearing that Dr Bauerstein had been at Styles on the fatal night and added
quote.s:
"And I've been thinking. You
know Inglethorp said he had put down the coffee in the hall? Well, it
was just then that Bauerstein arrived. Isn't it possible that, as
Inglethorp brought him through the hall, the doctor dropped something
into the coffee in passing?"
"It would have been very risky."
"Yes, but it was possible."
"And then, how could he know it was her coffee? No, old fellow, I don't\nthink that will wash."

div.p: But I had remembered something else.

quote.s: "You're quite right. That wasn't how it was done. Listen."

div.p: And I then told him of the cocoa sample which Poirot had taken to be analysed.
John interrupted just as I had done.

quote.s: "But, look here, Bauerstein had had it analysed already?"

"Yes, yes, that's the point. I didn't see it either until now. Don't
you understand? Bauerstein had it analysed that's just it! If
Bauerstein's the murderer, nothing could be simpler than for him to
substitute some ordinary cocoa for his sample, and send that to be
tested. And of course they would find no strychnine! But no one would
dream of suspecting Bauerstein, or think of taking another
sample except Poirot,"

div.p: I added, with belated recognition.

quote.s: "Yes, but what about the bitter taste that cocoa won't disguise?"
"Well, we've only his word for that. And there are other possibilities.\nHe's admittedly one of the world's greatest toxicologists"
"One of the world's greatest what? Say it again."

"Well,
my idea is, that perhaps he's found some way of making strychnine
tasteless. Or it may not have been strychnine at all, but some obscure
drug no one has ever heard of, which produces much the same symptoms."
"But look here, how could he have\ngot at the cocoa? That wasn't downstairs?"
"No, it wasn't,"

div.p: I admitted reluctantly.

And then, suddenly, a dreadful possibility flashed through my mind. I hoped and prayed it would not occur to John also. I glanced sideways at him. He was frowning perplexedly, and I drew a deep breath of relief, for the terrible thought that had flashed across my mind was this: that Dr. Bauerstein might have had an accomplice.
Yet surely it could not be! Surely no woman as beautiful as Mary Cavendish could be a murderess. Yet beautiful women had been known to poison.

And suddenly I remembered that first conversation at tea on the day of my arrival, and the gleam in her eyes as she had said that poison was a woman's weapon. How agitated she had been on that fatal Tuesday evening! Had Mrs. Inglethorp discovered something between her and Bauerstein, and threatened to tell her husband? Was it to stop that denunciation that the crime had been committed?
Then I remembered that enigmatical conversation between Poirot and Evelyn Howard. Was this what they had meant? Was this the monstrous possibility that Evelyn had tried not to believe?
Yes, it all fitted in.

No wonder Miss Howard had suggested "hushing it up." Now I understood that unfinished sentence of hers: "Emily herself " And in my heart I agreed with her. Would not Mrs. Inglethorp have preferred to go unavenged rather than have such terrible dishonour fall upon the name of Cavendish.

quote.s: "Something which makes me doubt if\nwhat you say can be true."
"What's that?"

div.p: I asked, thankful that he had gone away from the subject of how the poison could have been introduced into the cocoa.

quote.s: "Why, the fact that Bauerstein demanded a post-mortem. He needn't have\ndone so. Little Wilkins would have been quite content to let it go at\nheart disease."

"But we don't know. Perhaps he thought it
safer in the long run. Someone might have talked afterwards. Then the
Home Office might have ordered exhumation. The whole thing would have
come out, then, and he would have been in an awkward position, for no
one would have believed that a man of his reputation could have been
deceived into calling it heart disease."
"Yes, that's possible,"

div.p: admitted John.

quote.s: "I'm blest if\nI can see what his motive could have been."

div.p: I trembled.

quote.s: "I may be altogether wrong. And, remember, all\nthis is in confidence."
"Oh, of course that goes without saying."

div.p: We had walked, as we talked, and now we passed through the little gate into the garden. Voices rose near at hand, for tea was spread out under the sycamore-tree, as it had been on the day of my arrival.
Cynthia was back from the hospital, and I placed my chair beside her, and told her of Poirot's wish to visit the dispensary.

quote.s:
"Of course! I'd love him to see it. He'd better come to tea there one
day. I must fix it up with him. He's such a dear little man! But he
is funny. He made me take the brooch out of my tie the other day, and
put it in again, because he said it wasn't straight."

div.p: I laughed.

quote.s: "It's quite a mania with him."
"Yes, isn't it?"

div.p: We were silent for a minute or two, and then, glancing in the direction of Mary Cavendish, and dropping her voice, Cynthia said:

quote.s: "Mr. Hastings."
"Yes?"
"After tea, I want to talk to you."

div.p: Her glance at Mary had set me thinking. I fancied that between these two there existed very little sympathy. For the first time, it occurred to me to wonder about the girl's future. Mrs. Inglethorp had made no provisions of any kind for her, but I imagined that John and Mary would probably insist on her making her home with them at any rate until the end of the war. John, I knew, was very fond of her, and would be sorry to let her go.
John, who had gone into the house, now reappeared. His good-natured face wore an unaccustomed frown of anger.

quote.s:
"Confound those detectives! I can't think what they're after! They've
been in every room in the house turning things inside out, and upside
down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all
being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!"
"Lot of Paul Prys,"

div.p: grunted Miss Howard.
Lawrence opined that they had to make a show of doing something.
Mary Cavendish said nothing.
After tea, I invited Cynthia to come for a walk, and we sauntered off into the woods together.

quote.s: "Well?"

div.p: I inquired, as soon as we were protected from prying eyes by the leafy screen.
With a sigh, Cynthia flung herself down, and tossed off her hat. The sunlight, piercing through the branches, turned the auburn of her hair to quivering gold.

quote.s: "Mr. Hastings you are always so kind, and you know such a lot."

div.p: It struck me at this moment that Cynthia was really a very charming girl! Much more charming than Mary, who never said things of that kind.

quote.s: "Well?"

div.p: I asked benignantly, as she hesitated.

quote.s: "I want to ask your advice. What shall I do?"
"Do?"

"Yes. You see, Aunt Emily always told me I should be provided for. I
suppose she forgot, or didn't think she was likely to die anyway, I am
not provided for! And I don't know what to do. Do you think I ought
to go away from here at once?"
"Good heavens, no! They don't want to part with you, I'm sure."

div.p: Cynthia hesitated a moment, plucking up the grass with her tiny hands. Then she said:

quote.s: "Mrs. Cavendish does. She hates me."
"Hates you?"

div.p: I cried, astonished.
Cynthia nodded.

quote.s: "Yes. I don't know why, but she can't bear me; and he can't, either."
"On the contrary, John is\nvery fond of you."
"Oh, yes John. I meant Lawrence. Not, of course, that I care whether\nLawrence hates me or not. Still, it's rather horrid when no one loves\nyou, isn't it?"
"I'm sure you are\nmistaken. Look, there is John and Miss Howard"

div.p: Cynthia nodded rather gloomily.

quote.s:
"Yes, John likes me, I think, and of
course Evie, for all her gruff ways, wouldn't be unkind to a fly. But
Lawrence never speaks to me if he can help it, and Mary can hardly
bring herself to be civil to me. She wants Evie to stay on, is begging
her to, but she doesn't want me, and and I don't know what to do."

div.p: Suddenly the poor child burst out crying.

I don't know what possessed me. Her beauty, perhaps, as she sat there, with the sunlight glinting down on her head; perhaps the sense of relief at encountering someone who so obviously could have no connection with the tragedy; perhaps honest pity for her youth and loneliness. Anyway, I leant forward, and taking her little hand, I said awkwardly:

quote.s: "Marry me, Cynthia."

div.p: Unwittingly, I had hit upon a sovereign remedy for her tears. She sat up at once, drew her hand away, and said, with some asperity:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: She sat up at once drew her hand away and said
quote.s: "Don't be silly!"

div.p: I was a little annoyed.

quote.s: "I'm not being silly. I am asking you to do me the honour of becoming\nmy wife."

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Cynthia burst out laughing and called me
quote.s: "funny dear."
"but you know you don't want\nto!"
"Yes, I do. I've got"
"Never mind what you've got. You don't really want to and I don't\neither."
"But I don't see\nanything to laugh at. There's nothing funny about a proposal."
"Somebody might accept you next time.\nGood-bye, you've cheered me up very much."

div.p: To my intense surprise, Cynthia burst out laughing, and called me a And, with a final uncontrollable burst of merriment, she vanished through the trees.
Thinking over the interview, it struck me as being profoundly unsatisfactory.

It occurred to me suddenly that I would go down to the village, and look up Bauerstein. Somebody ought to be keeping an eye on the fellow. At the same time, it would be wise to allay any suspicions he might have as to his being suspected. I remembered how Poirot had relied on my diplomacy. Accordingly, I went to the little house with the Apartments" card inserted in the window, where I knew he lodged, and tapped on the door.
An old woman came and opened it.

quote.s: "Is Dr. Bauerstein in?"

div.p: She stared at me.

quote.s: "Haven't you heard?"
"Heard what?"
"About him."
"What about him?"
"He's took."
"Took? Dead?"
"No, took by the perlice."
"Do you mean they've arrested him?"
"Yes, that's it, and"

div.p: I waited to hear no more, but tore up the village to find Poirot.
div.head: CHAPTER X.
THE ARREST
div.p: To my extreme annoyance, Poirot was not in, and the old Belgian who answered my knock informed me that he believed he had gone to London.
I was dumbfounded. What on earth could Poirot be doing in London! Was it a sudden decision on his part, or had he already made up his mind when he parted from me a few hours earlier?

I retraced my steps to Styles in some annoyance. With Poirot away, I was uncertain how to act. Had he foreseen this arrest? Had he not, in all probability, been the cause of it? Those questions I could not resolve. But in the meantime what was I to do? Should I announce the arrest openly at Styles, or not? Though I did not acknowledge it to myself, the thought of Mary Cavendish was weighing on me. Would it not be a terrible shock to her? For the moment, I set aside utterly any suspicions of her. She could not be implicated otherwise I should have heard some hint of it.

Of course, there was no possibility of being able permanently to conceal Dr. Bauerstein's arrest from her. It would be announced in every newspaper on the morrow. Still, I shrank from blurting it out. If only Poirot had been accessible, I could have asked his advice. What possessed him to go posting off to London in this unaccountable way?

In spite of myself, my opinion of his sagacity was immeasurably heightened. I would never have dreamt of suspecting the doctor, had not Poirot put it into my head. Yes, decidedly, the little man was clever.
After some reflecting, I decided to take John into my confidence, and leave him to make the matter public or not, as he thought fit.
He gave vent to a prodigious whistle, as I imparted the news.

quote.s: "Great Scott! You were right, then. I couldn't believe it at the\ntime."
"No, it is astonishing until you get used to the idea, and see how it\nmakes everything fit in. Now, what are we to do? Of course, it will be\ngenerally known to-morrow."

div.p: John reflected.

quote.s: "we won't say anything at present. There\nis no need. As you say, it will be known soon enough."

div.p: But to my intense surprise, on getting down early the next morning, and eagerly opening the newspapers, there was not a word about the arrest! There was a column of mere padding about "The Styles Poisoning Case, but nothing further. It was rather inexplicable, but I supposed that, for some reason or other, Japp wished to keep it out of the papers. It worried me just a little, for it suggested the possibility that there might be further arrests to come.
After breakfast, I decided to go down to the village, and see if Poirot had returned yet; but, before I could start, a well-known face blocked one of the windows, and the well-known voice said:

quote.s: "Bonjour, mon ami!"
"I was never so glad to see anyone. Listen,\nI have said nothing to anybody but John. Is that right?"
"I do not know what you are talking\nabout."
"Dr. Bauerstein's arrest, of course,"

div.p: I answered impatiently.

quote.s: "Is Bauerstein arrested, then?"
"Did you not know it?"
"Not the least in the world."

div.p: But, pausing a moment, he added:

quote.s: "Still,\nit does not surprise me. After all, we are only four miles from the\ncoast."
"What has that got to do with it?"

div.p: Poirot shrugged his shoulders.

quote.s: "Surely, it is obvious!"
"Not to me. No doubt I am very dense, but I cannot see what the\nproximity of the coast has got to do with the murder of Mrs.\nInglethorp."
"But we were\nspeaking of the arrest of Dr. Bauerstein."
"Well, he is arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp"
"Dr.\nBauerstein arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp?"
"Yes."
"Impossible! That would be too good a farce! Who told you that, my\nfriend?"
"But he is arrested."
"Oh, yes, very likely. But for espionage, mon ami."
"Espionage?"

div.p: I gasped.

quote.s: "Precisely."
"Not for poisoning Mrs. Inglethorp?"
"Not unless our friend Japp has taken leave of his senses,"

div.p: replied Poirot placidly.

quote.s: "But but I thought you thought so too?"

div.p: Poirot gave me one look, which conveyed a wondering pity, and his full sense of the utter absurdity of such an idea.

quote.s: "that Dr. Bauerstein is a spy?"

div.p: Poirot nodded.

quote.s: "Have you never suspected it?"
"It never entered my head."

"It did not strike you as peculiar that a famous London doctor should\nbury himself in a little village like this, and should be in the habit\nof walking about at all hours of the night, fully dressed?"
"I never thought of such a thing."
"though he has practised so long in this country that nobody thinks of\nhim as anything but an Englishman. He was naturalized about fifteen\nyears ago. A very clever man a Jew, of course."
"The blackguard!"

div.p: I cried indignantly.

quote.s: "Not at all. He is, on the contrary, a patriot. Think what he stands to\nlose. I admire the man myself."

div.p: But I could not look at it in Poirot's philosophical way.

quote.s: "And this is the man with whom Mrs. Cavendish has been wandering about\nall over the country!"

div.p: I cried indignantly.

quote.s: "So long as gossip busied itself in coupling their names together, any\nother vagaries of the doctor's passed unobserved."
"Then you think he never really cared for her?"

div.p: I asked eagerly rather too eagerly, perhaps, under the circumstances.

quote.s: "That, of course, I cannot say, but shall I tell you my own private\nopinion, Hastings?"
"Yes."
"Well, it is this: that Mrs. Cavendish does not care, and never has\ncared one little jot about Dr. Bauerstein!"
"Do you really think so?"

div.p: I could not disguise my pleasure.

quote.s: "I am quite sure of it. And I will tell you why."
"Yes?"
"Because she cares for someone else, mon ami."
"Oh!"

div.p: What did he mean? In spite of myself, an agreeable warmth spread over me. I am not a vain man where women are concerned, but I remembered certain evidences, too lightly thought of at the time, perhaps, but which certainly seemed to indicate

My pleasing thoughts were interrupted by the sudden entrance of Miss Howard. She glanced round hastily to make sure there was no one else in the room, and quickly produced an old sheet of brown paper. This she handed to Poirot, murmuring as she did so the cryptic words:

quote.s: "On top of the wardrobe."

div.p: Then she hurriedly left the room.
Poirot unfolded the sheet of paper eagerly, and uttered an exclamation of satisfaction. He spread it out on the table.

quote.s: "Come here, Hastings. Now tell me, what is that initial J. or L.?"

div.p: It was a medium sized sheet of paper, rather dusty, as though it had lain by for some time. But it was the label that was attracting Poirot's attention. At the top, it bore the printed stamp of Messrs. Parkson's, the well-known theatrical costumiers, and it was addressed to " (the debatable initial) Cavendish, Esq., Styles Court, Styles St. Mary, Essex.

quote.s: "It certainly isn't a J."
"I, also, am of\nyour way of thinking. It is an L., depend upon it!"
"Is it important?"
"Moderately so. It confirms a surmise of mine. Having deduced its\nexistence, I set Miss Howard to search for it, and, as you see, she has\nbeen successful."
"What did she mean by"

div.p: On the top of the wardrobe'?

quote.s: "that she found it on top of a\nwardrobe."
"A funny place for a piece of brown paper,"

div.p: I mused.

quote.s: "Not at all. The top of a wardrobe is an excellent place for brown\npaper and cardboard boxes. I have kept them there myself. Neatly\narranged, there is nothing to offend the eye."
"have you made up your mind about this\ncrime?"
"Yes that is to say, I believe I know how it was committed."
"Ah!"
"Unfortunately, I have no proof beyond my surmise, unless"

div.p: With sudden energy, he caught me by the arm, and whirled me down the hall, calling out in French in his excitement:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he caught me by the arm and whirled me down the hall calling out
quote.s: "Mademoiselle Dorcas,\nMademoiselle Dorcas, un moment, s'il vous pla t!"

div.p: Dorcas, quite flurried by the noise, came hurrying out of the pantry.

quote.s:
"My good Dorcas, I have an idea a little idea if it should prove
justified, what magnificent chance! Tell me, on Monday, not Tuesday,
Dorcas, but Monday, the day before the tragedy, did anything go wrong
with Mrs. Inglethorp's bell?"

div.p: Dorcas looked very surprised.

quote.s: "Yes, sir, now you mention it, it did; though I don't know how you came\nto hear of it. A mouse, or some such, must have nibbled the wire\nthrough. The man came and put it right on Tuesday morning."

div.p: With a long drawn exclamation of ecstasy, Poirot led the way back to the morning-room.

quote.s:
"See you, one should not ask for outside proof no, reason should be
enough. But the flesh is weak, it is consolation to find that one is on
the right track. Ah, my friend, I am like a giant refreshed. I run! I
leap!"

div.p: And, in very truth, run and leap he did, gambolling wildly down the stretch of lawn outside the long window.

quote.s: "What is it all about?"
"Really, I can't tell you. He asked Dorcas some question about a bell,\nand appeared so delighted with her answer that he is capering about as\nyou see!"

div.p: Mary laughed.

quote.s: "How ridiculous! He's going out of the gate. Isn't he coming back\nto-day?"
"I don't know. I've given up trying to guess what he'll do next."
"Is he quite mad, Mr. Hastings?"
"I honestly don't know. Sometimes, I feel sure he is as mad as a\nhatter; and then, just as he is at his maddest, I find there is method\nin his madness."
"I see."

div.p: In spite of her laugh, Mary was looking thoughtful this morning. She seemed grave, almost sad.
It occurred to me that it would be a good opportunity to tackle her on the subject of Cynthia. I began rather tactfully, _I_ thought, but I had not gone far before she stopped me authoritatively.

quote.s: "You are an excellent advocate, I have no doubt, Mr. Hastings, but in\nthis case your talents are quite thrown away. Cynthia will run no risk\nof encountering any unkindness from me."

div.p: I began to stammer feebly that I hoped she hadn't thought But again she stopped me, and her words were so unexpected that they quite drove Cynthia, and her troubles, out of my mind.

quote.s: "whether it is your business or not, I will\ntell you that we are not happy."

div.p: I said nothing, for I saw that she had not finished.
She began slowly, walking up and down the room, her head a little bent, and that slim, supple figure of hers swaying gently as she walked. She stopped suddenly, and looked up at me.

quote.s:
"Where I come
from, who I was before I married John anything, in fact? Well, I will
tell you. I will make a father confessor of you. You are kind, I
think yes, I am sure you are kind."

div.p: Somehow, I was not quite as elated as I might have been. I remembered that Cynthia had begun her confidences in much the same way. Besides, a father confessor should be elderly, it is not at all the role for a young man.

quote.s: "but my mother was a\nRussian."
"now I understand"
"Understand what?"
"A hint of something foreign different that there has always been about\nyou."

"My mother was very beautiful, I believe. I don't know, because I never
saw her. She died when I was quite a little child. I believe there was
some tragedy connected with her death she took an overdose of some
sleeping draught by mistake. However that may be, my father was
broken-hearted. Shortly afterwards, he went into the Consular Service.
Everywhere he went, I went with him. When I was twenty-three, I had
been nearly all over the world. It was a splendid life I loved it."

div.p: There was a smile on her face, and her head was thrown back. She seemed living in the memory of those old glad days.

quote.s: "Then my father died. He left me very badly off. I had to go and live\nwith some old aunts in Yorkshire."

div.p: She shuddered.

quote.s: "You will understand\nme when I say that it was a deadly life for a girl brought up as I had\nbeen. The narrowness, the deadly monotony of it, almost drove me mad."

div.p: She paused a minute, and added in a different tone:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: She paused a minute and added
quote.s: "And then I met\nJohn Cavendish."
"Yes?"

"You can imagine that, from my aunts' point of view, it was a very good
match for me. But I can honestly say it was not this fact which weighed
with me. No, he was simply a way of escape from the insufferable
monotony of my life."

div.p: I said nothing, and after a moment, she went on:

quote.s:
"Don't misunderstand me. I was quite honest with him. I told him, what
was true, that I liked him very much, that I hoped to come to like him
more, but that I was not in any way what the world calls in love' with
him. He declared that that satisfied him, and so we were married."

div.p: She waited a long time, a little frown had gathered on her forehead. She seemed to be looking back earnestly into those past days.

quote.s: "I think I am sure he cared for me at first. But I suppose we were not\nwell matched. Almost at once, we drifted apart. He it is not a pleasing\nthing for my pride, but it is the truth tired of me very soon."

div.p: I must have made some murmur of dissent, for she went on quickly:

quote.s: "Oh, yes, he\ndid! Not that it matters now now that we've come to the parting of the\nways."
"What do you mean?"

div.p: She answered quietly:

quote.s: "I mean that I am not going to remain at Styles."
"You and John are not going to live here?"
"John may live here, but I shall not."
"You are going to leave him?"
"Yes."
"But why?"

div.p: She paused a long time, and said at last:

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: She paused a long time and said
quote.s: "Perhaps because I want to be free!"

div.p: And, as she spoke, I had a sudden vision of broad spaces, virgin tracts of forests, untrodden lands and a realization of what freedom would mean to such a nature as Mary Cavendish. I seemed to see her for a moment as she was, a proud wild creature, as untamed by civilization as some shy bird of the hills. A little cry broke from her lips:

quote.s: "You don't know, you don't know, how this hateful place has been prison\nto me!"
"but but don't do anything rash."
"Oh, rash!"

div.p: Her voice mocked at my prudence.
Then suddenly I said a thing I could have bitten out my tongue for:

quote.s: "You know that Dr. Bauerstein has been arrested?"

div.p: An instant coldness passed like a mask over her face, blotting out all expression.

quote.s: "John was so kind as to break that to me this morning."
"Well, what do you think?"

div.p: I asked feebly.

quote.s: "Of what?"
"Of the arrest?"
"What should I think? Apparently he is a German spy; so the gardener\nhad told John."

div.p: Her face and voice were absolutely cold and expressionless. Did she care, or did she not?
She moved away a step or two, and fingered one of the flower vases.

quote.s: "These are quite dead. I must do them again. Would you mind\nmoving thank you, Mr. Hastings."

div.p: And she walked quietly past me out of the window, with a cool little nod of dismissal.
No, surely she could not care for Bauerstein. No woman could act her part with that icy unconcern.
Poirot did not make his appearance the following morning, and there was no sign of the Scotland Yard men.

But, at lunch-time, there arrived a new piece of evidence or rather lack of evidence. We had vainly tried to trace the fourth letter, which Mrs. Inglethorp had written on the evening preceding her death. Our efforts having been in vain, we had abandoned the matter, hoping that it might turn up of itself one day. And this is just what did happen, in the shape of a communication, which arrived by the second post from a firm of French music publishers, acknowledging Mrs. Inglethorp's cheque, and regretting they had been unable to trace a certain series of Russian folksongs. So the last hope of solving the mystery, by means of Mrs. Inglethorp's correspondence on the fatal evening, had to be abandoned.
Just before tea, I strolled down to tell Poirot of the new disappointment, but found, to my annoyance, that he was once more out.

quote.s: "Gone to London again?"

div.p: Oh, no, monsieur, he has but taken the train to Tadminster. To see a young lady's dispensary,' he said.

quote.s: "I told him Wednesday was the one day she\nwasn't there! Well, tell him to look us up to-morrow morning, will\nyou?"

div.p: Certainly, monsieur.
But, on the following day, no sign of Poirot. I was getting angry. He was really treating us in the most cavalier fashion.
After lunch, Lawrence drew me aside, and asked if I was going down to see him.

quote.s: "No, I don't think I shall. He can come up here if he wants to see us."
"Oh!"

div.p: Lawrence looked indeterminate. Something unusually nervous and excited in his manner roused my curiosity.

quote.s: "I could go if there's anything special."
"It's nothing much, but well, if you are going, will you tell him"

div.p: he dropped his voice to a whisper

quote.s: "I think I've found the extra\ncoffee-cup!"

div.p: I had almost forgotten that enigmatical message of Poirot's, but now my curiosity was aroused afresh.
Lawrence would say no more, so I decided that I would descend from my high horse, and once more seek out Poirot at Leastways Cottage.
This time I was received with a smile. Monsieur Poirot was within. Would I mount? I mounted accordingly.
Poirot was sitting by the table, his head buried in his hands. He sprang up at my entrance.

quote.s: "You are not ill, I trust?"
"No, no, not ill. But I decide an affair of great moment."
"Whether to catch the criminal or not?"

div.p: I asked facetiously.
But, to my great surprise, Poirot nodded gravely.

quote.s: "To speak or not to speak,' as your so great Shakespeare says,"

div.p: that is the question.'
I did not trouble to correct the quotation.

quote.s: "You are not serious, Poirot?"
"I am of the most serious. For the most serious of all things hangs in\nthe balance."
"And that is?"
"A woman's happiness, mon ami,"

div.p: he said gravely.
I did not quite know what to say.

quote.s: "and I do not know\nwhat to do. For, see you, it is a big stake for which I play. No one\nbut I, Hercule Poirot, would attempt it!"

div.p: And he tapped himself proudly on the breast.
After pausing a few minutes respectfully, so as not to spoil his effect, I gave him Lawrence's message.

quote.s: "So he has found the extra coffee-cup. That is good.\nHe has more intelligence than would appear, this long-faced Monsieur\nLawrence of yours!"

div.p: I did not myself think very highly of Lawrence's intelligence; but I forebore to contradict Poirot, and gently took him to task for forgetting my instructions as to which were Cynthia's days off.

quote.s: "It is true. I have the head of a sieve. However, the other young lady\nwas most kind. She was sorry for my disappointment, and showed me\neverything in the kindest way."
"Oh, well, that's all right, then, and you must go to tea with Cynthia\nanother day."

div.p: I told him about the letter.

quote.s: "as\nyou say over here."

div.p: Then, suddenly, he asked:

quote.s: "Are you a judge of\nfinger-marks, my friend?"
"I know that there are no two\nfinger-marks alike, but that's as far as my science goes."
"Exactly."

div.p: He unlocked a little drawer, and took out some photographs which he laid on the table.

quote.s: "I have numbered them, 1, 2, 3. Will you describe them to me?"

div.p: I studied the proofs attentively.

quote.s: "All greatly magnified, I see. No. 1, I should say, are a man's\nfinger-prints; thumb and first finger. No. 2 are a lady's; they are\nmuch smaller, and quite different in every way. No. 3"

div.p: I paused for some time

quote.s: "there seem to be a lot of confused finger-marks, but here,\nvery distinctly, are No. 1's."
"Overlapping the others?"
"Yes."
"You recognize them beyond fail?"
"Oh, yes; they are identical."

div.p: Poirot nodded, and gently taking the photographs from me locked them up again.

quote.s: "that as usual, you are not going to explain?"

"On the contrary. No. 1 were the finger-prints of Monsieur Lawrence.
No. 2 were those of Mademoiselle Cynthia. They are not important. I
merely obtained them for comparison. No. 3 is a little more
complicated."
"Yes?"

"It is, as you see, highly magnified. You may have noticed a sort of
blur extending all across the picture. I will not describe to you the
special apparatus, dusting powder, etc., which I used. It is a
well-known process to the police, and by means of it you can obtain a
photograph of the finger-prints of any object in a very short space of
time. Well, my friend, you have seen the finger-marks it remains to
tell you the particular object on which they had been left."
"Go on I am really excited."

"Eh bien! Photo No. 3 represents the highly magnified surface of a
tiny bottle in the top poison cupboard of the dispensary in the Red
Cross Hospital at Tadminster which sounds like the house that Jack
built!"
"But what were Lawrence Cavendish's\nfinger-marks doing on it? He never went near the poison cupboard the\nday we were there!"
"Oh, yes, he did!"
"Impossible! We were all together the whole time."

div.p: Poirot shook his head.

quote.s:
"No, my friend, there was a moment when you were not all together.
There was a moment when you could not have been all together, or it
would not have been necessary to call to Monsieur Lawrence to come and
join you on the balcony."
"But it was only for a moment."
"Long enough."
"Long enough for what?"

div.p: Poirot's smile became rather enigmatical.
